characters: SHOTS ARE HAND-HELD AND WILL CONVEY THE DRAMA AND IMMEDIA
OF PIANO MUSIC. NO PRODUCTION SOUND IS HEARD. THE FOLLOWI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man with his back to the camera. A harness hangs from h back. A frantic reeling action with his arms as he gather a silk parachute. The action JUMP CUTS as he buries the c into the snow. This is JAN KUBIS, 29. Strong slender frame. JAN stands up into frame, his back still to the CAMERA. SOUND OFF: A muffled scream. JAN turns his head to where sound came from and listens. He tries to control his fast breaths, the moonlit backlights the vapour against the da forest. He looks sensitive but determined. A thinking man. The forest silent except for his own breathing. The sound again. JAN takes off in its direction. Various fast paced TRACKING shots until JAN stops ina clearing and sees: JOSEF GABCIK, 30. Volatile and demonstrative in equal measures. Part of JOSEF’s parachute has snagged on a pine tree. He attempting to pull it down and is unsteady on his feet. H grimacing in pain. JAN arrives and they pull the parachut free and start to bury it.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Where is the equipment? JOSEF turns and indicates behind them: JAN turns and sees a parachute caught impossibly high up pine tree. A metal container gently dangles below the entanglement.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: (under his breath) Kurva! JAN looks back and sees that JOSEF is limping on one foot

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Caught one of the branches on the way down.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Can you move?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAN'’s arms are around JOSEF as he helps him along a snow track over-shadowed by trees. CAMERA follows them from behind. CLOSE UP: Two pairs of feet hurrying through the snow. On pair badly limping and leaving a deep red blood trail thr white snow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small fire. JAN eats some rations. JOSEF removes his boot. His sock is sticky with dark bloo He pulls down the sock to reveal a deep cut on his ankle. JAN inspects the wound.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: You’1l need stitches. JAN rips a rag from his pack and helps JOSEF dress the wo JAN then sees a small piece of wood on the cave floor. He picks it up and inspects it. He takes his knife from his belt, sits with his back to the cave wall and starts to whittle the wood with his knife.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fire has smouldered into grey ash. The two men are asleep. There’s a noise. JAN opens his eyes and sees at the mouth the cave a figure. This is ANTONIN, a middle-aged stocky farmer, brutish in manner, holding a shotgun with a dog a his feet. JAN wakens JOSEF. There’s a momentary silence a the three eye each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn’t hide your parachutes very well and you left a blood trail for half a kilometer. Silence. Nobody moves.

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIN
dialogues.text: Follow me. I live not far from here. JOSEF and JAN get to their feet groggily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A snow-covered landscape. In the middle distance is ANTON who turns and urges them to keep up. JOSEF and JAN exchange apprehensive glances. A clearing in the woods. JAN scans and sees: A small farmhouse with a barn. Pens for livestock, a truc sits parked next to a stone well. Self sufficient.

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIN
dialogues.text: Ignac! (beat)

dialogues.speaker: IGNAC
dialogues.text: A few moments later IGNAC appears in the doorway of the farmhouse. A tousle-haired youth in his late teens with a acned face. IGNAC has on an leather apron stained with bl He has a carving belt with a number of knives held in pla

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIN
dialogues.text: Prepare some food. IGNAC turns and runs back inside.

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIN
dialogues.text: Hot soup. Come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some nasty soup is poured into bowls. IGNAC places the bo in front of JAN and JOSEF. JAN shares a concerned look with JOSEF. The farmhouse loo run down and in need of repair.

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIN
dialogues.text: Please, eat. JAN and JOSEF slowly lift the spoons to their mouths. The scene awkward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I take it you are heading for Prague?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Yes. How far away is it?

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIN
dialogues.text: 30 Kilometers. I have a special delivery permit for my truck. (beat) I could take you. JAN looks at JOSEF and then at ANTONIN.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: (appreciative) Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIN
dialogues.text: Well that’s settled. You rest here tonight and I will take you in the morning. ANTONIN exchanges a look with IGNAC and then stands up fr the table.

dialogues.speaker: ANTONIN
dialogues.text: Enjoy your soup. ANTONIN leaves the room, closing the door behind him. JAN JOSEF are left with IGNAC who looks like he never went to school. JOSEF looks at JAN. Something is wrong. The silence in th room oppressive. A clock gently ticks somewhere. JOSEF suddenly stands up and strides towards the kitchen and bursts through into the hall to find ANTONIN standing the hallway on the telephone. JOSEF steps forward, takes a pistol from his pocket and a it at ANTONIN’s head. ANTONIN like a rabbit caught in the headlights, slowly pu the phone down and raises his hands in the air.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: How much do you get for turning in parachutists to the Germans? ANTONIN just stares at him. Guilt written on his face. JOSEF grabs ANTONIN and pulls him back to the kitchen whe he finds JAN seated with his hands in the air and IGNAC holding a knife to his throat.

dialogues.speaker: IGNAC
dialogues.text: Drop the gun!

dialogues.speaker: ANTHROPOID V20
dialogues.text: JOSEF keeps the gun aimed at ANTONIN’s head. IGNAC reach inside JAN’s jacket and takes his gun.

dialogues.speaker: IGNAC
dialogues.text: I said drop the... SUDDENLY ANTONIN grabs the gun and he and JOSEF wrestle f control. JAN grabs IGNAC’s arm and kicks back and the two fly backwards and are stopped by the sink. IGNAC drops the knife and the gun - JAN drops for the gun IGNAC kicks it and skittles across the dank floor. IGNAC steps back and pulls another knife from his belt. ANTONIN is stronger and manages to pull the gun away from JOSEF. But in doing so, pulls the trigger, shooting himse in the face. Blood sprays across JOSEF’s stunned face. Everyone is momentarily frozen in shock. IGNAC looks at ANTONIN who is face down. He suddenly real he is now outnumbered. He turns and bolts out of a side d in the kitchen. JOSEF scuttles next to ANTONIN and retrieves his pistol f ANTONIN’s dead hand. JOSEF spins and throws the pistol through the air towards JAN. JAN catches it and chases after IGNAC. At the edge of the forest JAN stops running and aims the pistol. An expression of concentration. His stance traine like that of a soldier. JAN'’s POV: a clear shot of IGNAC as he runs deeper into forest. JAN’s concentration turns to hesitation. The hand that ho the gun starts to shake. More than hesitation - a mental block. JAN is hyperventilating. Pain across his face. Swe pours, JAN wipes his face and re-aims. JAN'’s POV: IGNAC disappears into the thick cover of the forest. JAN drops to his knees fighting for breath. Full-on panic attack. Fists clenched, muscles cramping. JAN fights it. Tries to calm himself. Slowly gets up, tur and makes his way back to the farmhouse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOSEF pulls the phone line from the wall. Takes a cloth a regards the dead weight of ANTONIN’s body on the kitchen floor. A pool of black blood slowly creeping across the floor. Josef wipes the blood from his face and exits. JAN approaching. More in control.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: You get him? JAN shakes his head no. JOSEF looks at JAN for a beat - JOSEF’s thoughts unreadable. He breaks off to survey the area.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: (nodding towards it) We'll take their truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAN drives. JOSEF looks out the window at the passing landscape. JAN steals a look at JOSEF. JOSEF notices.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: What? (beat) They had made their choice. (beat) Sometimes you have to pick a side. (beat) You would prefer it was us? JAN looks back to the road. The question hangs in the air JOSEF tears some cloth from a spare shirt and puts his fo on the dash. He changes the blood soaked rag for the new cloth and ties it tight.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: (indicating Josef's foot) We have to get that looked at as soon as possible.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: We have to make contact with the address in Prague first. (beat) We'll deal with this after. JAN gives him a worried look and then looks back at the r A squealing sound is heard over the engine. JOSEF turns, lifts the canvas and peers into the back of the truck. Six or seven pigs are in the back of the truck.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: A truck full of pigs! JOSEF sits back and for the first time the men share a sm at the situation they find themselves in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truck speeds past a sign post that indicates Prague i Kilometers away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Various shots as the truck makes its way through the stre of Prague.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOSEF checks his map and then the road ahead.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Should be the next left. Through the windows we see the heavy presence of the Germ army. Military trucks and soldiers very much in evidence every street corner. JAN turns the wheel and makes a left turn.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Pull over here. The truck comes to a stop as JOSEF looks up at an apartme block.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: This is it. JAN and JOSEF exit the truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both check the street with nervous glances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAN and JOSEF climbs the steps until they see a blue door with the number 44 on it. They have a quick look around and then nod to one another JAN knocks on the door and they wait. Footsteps are heard then the door opens. A plain looking WOMAN in her late thirties appears and lo at JAN and JOSEF.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: We are looking for Oldrich Novak. The woman looks at them. Uncertainty in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: The Novdkovi no longer live here. A silent beat.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: You have their new address? The WOMAN looks down and sees that JOSEF’s foot is bleedi and leaving a small pool of blood around his heal.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: I heard they were taken by the Gestapo a month before we moved into the apartment. From inside the apartment a MAN’s voice calls out.

dialogues.speaker: MAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: (turning inside briefly) Don’t worry, father. Just someone looking for directions. (back to Jan and Josef) I’m sorry, that is all I know.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: (stopping the door from closing) Please, can you help us?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: My father is not well, you must leave. JAN steps back from the door and JOSEF stares at the WOMA

dialogues.speaker: ANTHROPOID V20
dialogues.text: 18 19 The WOMAN locks eyes with JOSEF. A brief second passes.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: There is a veterinarian in the next row of shops up the street. (beat) I hear he is a good man. (beat) One that may help. JOSEF nods his thanks and they leave. INT. VETERINARIAN’S SURGERY - DAY 18 A small French bulldog is being held by an ELDERLY WOMAN while DR EDUARD, mid-50s bookish but kind, is trying to examine the dog. The dog is barking and trying to bite DR EDUARD.

dialogues.speaker: ELDERLY WOMAN
dialogues.text: He normally only barks at Germans!

dialogues.speaker: DR EDUARD
dialogues.text: Germans and anyone giving him a rectal examination. DR EDUARD removes his gloved hand from the dog’s rear and takes off the glove.

dialogues.speaker: DR EDUARD
dialogues.text: He should be fine now but don’t let him eat the rubbish around the bins again. From next door we hear the bell above the front door soun DR EDUARD looks up with slight concern - he is not expect any other clients today. He reassures the ELDERLY LADY wi warm smile. INT. VETERINARIAN’S RECEPTION - DAY 19 Frosted glass panels sit on top on wood panels and separa the reception from the surgery with a door in the centre.

dialogues.speaker: ELDERLY WOMAN
dialogues.text: (leading the dog out of the surgery) Thank you, Dr Eduard. Come along Benés! In the shop the ELDERLY WOMAN stops to see JAN and JOSEF the waiting area - neither have any pets. The ELDERLY WOMAN looks back at DR EDUARD with a slightly worried expression.

dialogues.speaker: DR EDUARD
dialogues.text: Look after him, Mrs Spinka.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHROPOID V20
dialogues.text: 20 MRS SPINKA leaves and DR EDUARD turns to JAN and JOSEF. A brief pause before we cut to: INT. VETERINARIAN’S SURGERY - DAY 20 A close up of JOSEF’s foot. A spot lamp lights a large cu that is being stitched together by DR EDUARD. Dark sticky blood surrounds the deep cut and five stitches hold most the wound together. DR EDUARD looks over his glasses at JAN who is peeking ou through the curtains. JAN's POV: Three German soldiers are roughly herding a Je family along the streets. Prodding them, shouting at them JAN walks back from the window and looks to JOSEF and the DR EDUARD.

dialogues.speaker: DR EDUARD
dialogues.text: Normally, for a dog bite, you would go to a hospital not a vet.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Did you know Oldrich Novak? DR EDUARD looks up to JAN and notices JAN’s right hand is stuffed into coat pocket and is obviously holding a pisto DR EDUARD looks back and continues to stitch JOSEF’s woun

dialogues.speaker: DR EDUARD
dialogues.text: Yes. He and his family were taken by the Gestapo.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: You know why?

dialogues.speaker: DR EDUARD
dialogues.text: They were suspected of anti-Nazi activities.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: And what if we were to say Oldrich Novak was our contact here in Prague? A beat.

dialogues.speaker: DR EDUARD
dialogues.text: Then I would have to wonder if you were ill informed Czech patriots or Gestapo spies trying to infiltrate what remains of the resistance? Silence. DR EDUARD looks at JAN’s bag on the floor. Insid can partly make out what looks like a decoder paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You sound Czech, I detect no German accent. Neither of you seem to have been beaten into coercion. You seem more concerned by the threat outside this room. The decoding paper in your bag doesn’t have a German font and given that this wound has more tree bark in it than dog bite, I would have to guess you have been parachuted back into Czechoslovakia with intelligence that is somewhat out of date. JOSEF winces as the last stitch is finished.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: You're a clever man. (beat) We were also told you were a good man... DR EDUARD stands and wipes his hands.

dialogues.speaker: DR EDUARD
dialogues.text: (holds out his hand) You have papers? JAN takes a wallet and removes his papers. JAN hands them over to DR EDUARD. An official looking document with JAN’s photograph attach

dialogues.speaker: DR EDUARD
dialogues.text: (inspecting the papers) Where were these made?

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: London, why what’s wrong?

dialogues.speaker: DR EDUARD
dialogues.text: (impressed face) Nothing. They’re good. He hands them back as a volley of shots is heard outside. JAN starts to go to the window. DR EDUARD stops him.

dialogues.speaker: DR EDUARD
dialogues.text: Don’t. You could draw attention. (beat) There is nothing we can do. You will get used to it. (beat) I’m not sure how long you have been away or what London has told you about what is going on here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think our current situation answers that, no?

dialogues.speaker: DR EDUARD
dialogues.text: Quite.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: We left for the defence of France and were evacuated to England when France fell to the Germans. (beat) It’s been a while.

dialogues.speaker: DR EDUARD
dialogues.text: Since Reinhard Heydrich was appointed Reich Protektor of the Czech lands, fear and suspicion rule. Rewards are given to people who inform on anti-Nazi activity. Handsome rewards. (beat) Heydrich has all but nearly crushed the resistance and has executed thousands of Czech nationals. (beat) Everyone is scared. DR EDUARD puts the final bandages on JOSEF’s foot.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: And you?

dialogues.speaker: DR EDUARD
dialogues.text: I’m just a vet. You didn’t give me much choice. (beat) I can put you in contact with the Miller. Maybe he can help you. (beat) If you can convince him. (beat) You can stay here tonight and I’1l contact the Miller in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: My friend here said you were a clever man. I agree. (indicates his hand in his pocket) Don’t do anything that would change our opinion. DR EDUARD nods to the men and then indicates JOSEF’s leg.

dialogues.speaker: DR EDUARD
dialogues.text: Go easy on the foot and you should be dancing the tango within the week.

dialogues.speaker: DAWN 21
dialogues.text: Over the rooftops. All is now quiet. The city starts to s INT. VETERINARIAN’S SURGERY - MORNING 22 JAN and JOSEF are ready and waiting. They look like they haven't slept. JOSEF is checking the street from the wind and JAN is whittling his piece of wood when the sound of are heard unlocking the front door. JAN opens the surgery door a crack and sees DR EDUARD ent with another man. He is BRETISLAV BAUMAN, a tall slim man his early fifties, educated but with a brusque manner. He a local miller but carries himself with the confidence of something more. His hand deep in his coat pocket proves i DR EDUARD stops when he sees JAN and JOSEF in defensive positions by the surgery door.

dialogues.speaker: DR EDUARD
dialogues.text: This is Bretislav the miller. BRETISLAV looks at JAN and JOSEF. A pause as they size ea other up.

dialogues.speaker: BRETISLAV
dialogues.text: Eduard told me you were looking for Oldrich Novak? JOSEF looks at BRETISLAV and nods.

dialogues.speaker: BRETISLAV
dialogues.text: Would you like to take a drive with me? Awkward pause. Nervous looks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRETISLAV drives with JAN and JOSEF on the bench seat nex him. A three-storey concrete building put up in the 1920s loom through the windshield. Cold and functional. The truck approaches and stops outside the entrance.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Where are all the students?

dialogues.speaker: BRETISLAV
dialogues.text: Closed. (beat) Germans don’t like colleges. They encourage people to think. (beat) Most of the academics and intellectuals have been shot.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHROPOID V20
dialogues.text: 24 25 26 BRETISLAV gets out the truck and starts walking across th courtyard and towards the school building.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: I think, stay on your toes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAN and JOSEF get out the truck and cross a courtyard and join BRETISLAV as they all enter through the main large doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAN, JOSEF and BRETISLAV walk down a long corridor, their footsteps echo. JOSEF looks around: empty class rooms. Some with chairs o turned. Paint peeling from the walls. Rust marks. Decay. doesn’t look good. JOSEF limps along and snatches a look at JAN. Both have a hand in their pocket. The corridor is long. Their footsteps echo out. Tensions breaking point. BRETISLAV looks back over his shoulder at JOSEF. JOSEF me his gaze. BRETISLAV turns back and reaches a doorway, goe through it. JAN and JOSEF follow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sitting behind a desk is a man. Standing next to him is another man. JAN and JOSEF enter but don’t see the two men either side the door they came through. “CLICK”. Pistols are trained on the back of JAN’s and JOS head. BRETISLAV spins, pistol trained on JAN and JOSEF.

dialogues.speaker: BRETISLAV
dialogues.text: Don’t move! JAN and JOSEF look around to assess the situation. Two ar men behind. BRETISLAV in front. Two men at the desk in fr BRETISLAV takes the pistols from JAN and JOSEF’s pockets. JOSEF looks very angry at himself for walking right into trap.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHROPOID V20
dialogues.text: BRETISLAV places the pistols on the desk in front of the seated man. He is JAN ZELENKA, a teacher, code-named ‘UNC HAJSKY’, an intellectual looking man in his early fifties Standing next to him is a tall slim man in his mid-fortie with a determined manner. He is LADISLAV VANEK. The men from behind place two chairs in front of the desk recede to cover at the back of the room.

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: (hand outstretched) Please sit. The room is silent.

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: You were looking for Oldrich Novak? JOSEF nods.

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: Why? JOSEF looks at them for what seems a long time. Weighing situation, the words he must use.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: He was our contact here in Prague. It hangs in the air.

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: Who gave you this contact?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: London. BRETISLAV and LADISLAV exchange looks.

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: And you tell us this because?

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: You are not leaving us much choice and this doesn’t look like Gestapo headquarters. LADISLAV turns to look at JAN.

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: You, where are you from? (beat) Your accent, Bohemia?

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: No, from Dolni Vilemovice, Moravia.

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: Then you must know the railway station at Vladislav?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: What’s so special about it? JAN thinks for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: I presume you are talking about the large bed of coloured roses that when seen from above is in the shape of our national flag? The men regard each other for a pregnant beat.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Is it still there?

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: Seems the Germans have still not looked at it from above... LADISLAV smiles. He pulls up a chair. Sits.

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: I am Vanek. Ladislav Vanek. (beat) I’m the head of the Jindra organization. (beat) Czech resistance. (beat) This is Jan Zelenka, code name Uncle Hajsky.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: I am Jan Kubis.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: I am Josef Gabcik. From Slovakia.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: You mustn’t be surprised by our lack of trust. The Gestapo have been very successful in infiltrating our network. (beat) The contact that London gave you, Oldrich Novak. He was taken away some months ago.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Well, that could have got us killed, why wasn’t London informed?

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: We lost contact with the Czech government-in-exile in London some months ago. We need replacement crystals for the transmitter. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been waiting for them to send someone to reestablish contact. (beat) Is that you?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: There were other men on our plane. They were dropped elsewhere, it’s possible they have orders to reestablish contact with London but I’m afraid that is not our mission.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: What is your mission? A long beat as JOSEF regards JAN.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: We are here as Operation Anthropoid.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: Derived from the Greek, Anthropos, It means, resembling a human being in form.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: We don’t know what it means other than the instructions given within the code name. There is a long silence in the room.

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: I take it you want our help for this mission? (beat) Whatever it is?

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Yes. We will need your help. Another silence.

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: We can help of course. But we need to know what you need help with. (beat) What is Anthropoid? JAN and JOSEF seem to be struggling with the information possess. LADISLAV tilts his head curiously at their struggle. UNCLE HAJSKY looks at LADISLAV and then back at JAN and JOSEF. It’s dawning on them just how big this mission cou be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are here to assassinate SS Obergruppenfiihrer Reinhard Heydrich. UNCLE HAJSKY and LADISLAV are frozen for a second. Blank faces just staring back.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: The Reichsprotektor of Bohemia and -

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY LADISLAV
dialogues.text: (interrupting) (overlapping) Yes, we know who he is... Are you completely mad?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF LADISLAV
dialogues.text: We have our orders, comrades. But this is madness! Heydrich! For Christ sakes, man!

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: (trying to interrupt) Ladislav...

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: Why stop with Heydrich? Why not have a go at Hitler as well? He’s only 300 kilometers down the road in a small village called Berlin.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: So we report to London that you are refusing to cooperate with our mission? LADISLAV loses it and kicks back his chair as he leaps to confrontational stance in front of JOSEF. JOSEF springs u and stands his ground.

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: How dare you question us! (beat) You know what we have sacrificed for the cause here? The men behind re-train their weapons at JOSEF. Silence as the men regard each other in the stand off.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: (calmly) Ladislav, please. Sit down... LADISLAV breaks the stare and returns to his seat as does JOSEF.

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: You kill Heydrich and Hitler will tear Prague apart. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I’m talking about the sort of reprisals we don’t want to imagine, can’t imagine. (beat) They will find a weak link, exploit it. Until someone gives them a name. Anyone that so much as sold a newspaper to that name will be shot. (beat) I take it you have family in Czechoslovakia? Mother? Father? (beat) You kill Heydrich then you can consider them and everyone that ever knew you dead...

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: All Czech patriots should be ready to die for their country. That includes my family.

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: (overlap) Well, I’m not! I want to carry on fighting. We don’t have that many left that are willing to do that. We are what’s left of the Czech resistance. We die, it dies. (beat) I suggest a lesser rank should be assassinated. Perhaps a few of them. (beat) We could look at Karl Frank or any of the puppets in the government here that collaborate with the Nazis.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Heydrich is the head of the secret police. Only Hitler and Himmler are above him in the Nazi hierarchy.

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: Exactly my point, you really think you'll ever get close enough to assassinate Heydrich? Silence. Doubt.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Our orders have come direct from the Czech Government in London.

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: So this is about the Czech government in London trying to impress the allies? (beat) What about when we had an army? Were willing to fight? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Able to fight? (beat) It was the allies that gave us to the Germans in the first place... (beat) Am I the only one that remembers the Munich agreement?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: Munich was a betrayal, but it’s also now history. The question the Czech Government in exile seems to be asking is this, are we still able to fight? Is Czechoslovakia still ready and able to resist Nazi Germany?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: The assassination of Reinhard Heydrich couldn’t send a clearer message to the world.

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: Yes, but at what cost? There is a heavy silence in the room.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: You have your orders. (beat) I’m sure Ladislav’s feelings will not colour his support. (beat) What do you need from us in the meantime?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Everything you know on Heydrich.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: I presume you want this down to the fine details of movements, planned engagements, and so on? JOSEF and JAN nod.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: It will take us a couple of weeks to figure out who we have on the inside that can get close to that kind of information.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: There is one other thing. (beat) We lost our equipment in the drop.

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: What do you need?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Two anti-tank grenades, model 73, 32 pounds of plastic explosives, two magazines of fuses, three timing pencils and one Sten Mark II machine gun with 100 rounds.

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: And where am I supposed to find all that?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Hanging thirty meters up from a pine tree, we can show you approximately where on a map.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: In the meantime I will take you to one of the safe houses we have in Prague. JAN and JOSEF understand with a grateful nod.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: UNCLE HAJSKY leads JOSEF and JAN up the steps of nondescr five-storey 1920s building. On the top floor UNCLE HAJSKY knocks on a door. MRS MORAVEC answers it. She is a strong looking woman in her late forties, dark hair with dark intense eyes that hint at her dependable resolve and her resistance to the German invasion of her motherland. Seeing UNCLE HAJSKY she ushers them inside with some urge

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A flat simply furnished in the Czech style. A violin is h practicing scales somewhere in the flat.

dialogues.speaker: MRS MORAVEC
dialogues.text: Good to see you, Uncle. You look in good health.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: And so do you, Mrs Moravec.

dialogues.speaker: MRS MORAVEC
dialogues.text: And who are these two exactly?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: Josef here, and this is Jan. JOSEF and JAN each shake MRS MORAVEC’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: MRS MORAVEC
dialogues.text: You are both most welcome here and please call me Auntie Moravec. (beat) Come on through, please. INT. MORAVEC FLAT, MAIN ROOM —- MORNING 30 A simple and modestly furnished room with large windows. dining table and chairs, several armchairs, a sofa, a cab with books. The kitchen leads off. MRS MORAVEC leads the three into the room.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: (to Josef and Jan) This will be your base for the time being. Mrs Moravec will look after you royally, I am sure.

dialogues.speaker: MRS MORAVEC
dialogues.text: My husband works on the railways and knows nothing of what we are doing. I‘’1l tell him that you are lodgers from the country seeking work. (calls over her shoulder) Ata! Ata! (beat) Ata is my son. He is studying to be a violinist.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: (to Josef and Jan) If you ever need to contact me, use Ata. ATA appears. A lean, friendly twenty-one-year-old.

dialogues.speaker: MRS MORAVEC
dialogues.text: Ata. This is Josef, and this is Jan.

dialogues.speaker: ATA
dialogues.text: I am pleased to meet you both. The three shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: (to Josef and Jan) A couple of things... (beat) Try not to go outside. (beat) If you must, never walk together. (beat) If you are stopped, you’ll need an excuse for not being at work. (beat) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will speak to our vet, the good Dr Eduard and see if he can get you medical certificates stating you are exempt from work. (beat) We use the code of three knocks followed by one knock. (beat) An open window with the curtain drawn is the danger signal. Stay away at all costs. (beat) Lay low until I can send word through Ata. The men nod. UNCLE HAJSKY bows to MRS MORAVEC and leaves. The men make a courtesy smile to MRS MORAVEC and then go about their business. They are checking every part of the flat: the windows, the locks, and so on. MRS MORAVEC looks on slightly anguished as she watches th systematically check everything.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: (pointing at the front door) That’s the only way in and out? MRS MORAVEC nods, hands held across her front.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: And the room we sleep in? MRS MORAVEC shows JAN and JOSEF to a little box room off corridor. A simple room. Two mattress beds on the floor. table and chair. A dresser and in an alcove, a sink with mirror above.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: JOSEF looks at JAN who has seen a skylight in the ceiling

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: (to Mrs Moravec) There’s a way off the roof?

dialogues.speaker: MRS MORAVEC
dialogues.text: (thinks ) There is a fire escape to the left. To the right it continues to the building next door.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: That’s good enough. JOSEF takes a chair and brings it to the door and wedges under the handle.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHROPOID V20
dialogues.text: JAN takes a tray of china from the table and lifts the t placing it under the skylight. He jumps on the table and easily opens the skylight and looks out. He then pokes hi head back in and gives a nod.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: OK. The chair stays by the door and the side table must always be clear of any china. MRS MORAVEC nods.

dialogues.speaker: MRS MORAVEC
dialogues.text: (slightly nervous) I am sure you both would like a glass of Becherovka.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Becherovka? Thank you. The front door is heard opening and JAN and JOSEF instant pull out their pistols. A female voice from the hallway.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE VOICE
dialogues.text: Mrs Moravec?

dialogues.speaker: MRS MORAVEC
dialogues.text: It’s OK. It’s Marie. MRS MORAVEC takes the chair from under the door handle. JAN and JOSEF hide their pistols. MRS MORAVEC opens the door and they exit to meet MARIE Kovarnikova in the hallway. MARIE is an attractive girl i her late teens bearing two heavy shopping bags. She freez in slight shock at the two strangers behind MRS MORAVEC.

dialogues.speaker: MRS MORAVEC
dialogues.text: It’s OK, Marie. This is Jan and Josef, my cousins from the country. They will be staying with us while they are looking for work.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: (formal) Pleased to meet you, Marie. JOSEF extends his hand. Somewhat shyly MARIE puts down the shopping bag and leans over to shake JOSEF’s hand. JAN smiles as he shakes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Hello.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHROPOID V20
dialogues.text: 31 There is a play between their eyes and its obvious that t is an attraction on JAN’s part. JOSEF notices.

dialogues.speaker: MRS MORAVEC
dialogues.text: Marie, Josef and Jan are not registered with the police as being residents here, so remember, please keep it strictly to yourself.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: (nods ) I‘1l put the shopping in the kitchen then. MRS MORAVEC smiles warmly at MARIE as she takes the shopp bags into the kitchen to unpack. JOSEF looks at MARIE leaving and then at MRS MORAVEC. He looks concerned.

dialogues.speaker: MRS MORAVEC
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, she is a trustworthy girl. Mrs Kovarnikova’s daughter. I pay her for helping out. (beat) I have to, I get no help from Ata, always on the violin. And as for Mr Moravec, he thinks he’s helping out if he closes a door. (beat) Dinner will be at 6pm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAN and JOSEF help lay plates onto the dinner table. MARIE helps MRS MORAVEC in the kitchen. MRS MORAVEC’s husband MR (Alois) MORAVEC is a large overweight man in his late forties with bushy eyebrows an bluff manner. He sits in a chair off to the side reading newspaper. ATA can be heard in the background playing the violin. Christmas decorations lightly decorate the apartment. The hot dishes are brought into the dining room. A modest feast is ready.

dialogues.speaker: MRS MORAVEC
dialogues.text: (calling out into the hall) Ata! Dinner is ready! MR MORAVEC gets out the chair and makes his way to the he of the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I’1ll be off now Mrs Moravec

dialogues.speaker: MRS MORAVEC
dialogues.text: Don’t be silly, Marie. Please stay and eat with us. We have enough. JAN steals a glance at MARIE who looks away.

dialogues.speaker: MRS MORAVEC
dialogues.text: Marie, I insist!

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: OK, then. Thank you. MARIE takes a seat opposite JAN. ATA enters the dining ro and sits down.

dialogues.speaker: MR MORAVEC
dialogues.text: (sighing) And finally the fiddler is silent!

dialogues.speaker: MRS MORAVEC
dialogues.text: (to Mr Moravec) He’s a violinist, Alois. A violinist!

dialogues.speaker: MR MORAVEC
dialogues.text: Well, whatever it is, and it wouldn't be so bad if he played something everyone knew.

dialogues.speaker: MRS MORAVEC
dialogues.text: (proudly to Jan and Josef) Ata is at the Conservatory for gifted musicians.

dialogues.speaker: MR MORAVEC
dialogues.text: Wasn’t interested in the railways, was he? Could be earning good money now as a clerk. I saw a future for him as a station master. (beat) Still, I suppose, the lad has to follow his own path. ATA has his face over his plate and is too busy eating to hear this old rant again.

dialogues.speaker: MR MORAVEC
dialogues.text: (to Jan and Josef) You two boys looking for work then?

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: (swallowing his food) Mmmm. Yes.

dialogues.speaker: MR MORAVEC
dialogues.text: We're always looking for boys in the railway shed, to clean the cinders out of the locomotives!

dialogues.speaker: MRS MORAVEC
dialogues.text: That is the dirtiest job in Prague! JAN steals a look at MARIE and MARIE looks away shyly.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Thank you for the offer, Mr Moravec. We’ll keep that in mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIE is at the sink cleaning the dishes. JAN brings in the last of the dishes from the table. JAN leans against the fridge and takes a cigarette packet from his pocket and offers one to MARIE. She shakes her head no. JAN lights up and takes a drag.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: So, what do you do when you aren’t helping out here? MARIE shrugs. There is a pause between them. Electricity fills the sile

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: You don’t have a boyfriend? Marie shrugs her shoulders shyly and is noncommittal. No special. There is tension and MARIE then breaks into a nervous gig JAN laughs a little too and the tension is relaxed. JOSEF enters with his plate. He looks at the two of them briefly before studying MARIE intensely.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: You like life in occupied Prague, Marie?

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: I take it not being registered with the police as residents has something to do with this question?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: It might. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: I hate the Germans.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHROPOID V20
dialogues.text: A beat.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: You have a friend as good looking as you? MARIE, looks to JAN and then back to JOSEF.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Seems Prague has changed since we were last here. (beat) Would be less conspicuous if we walked around with girls on our arms. (beat) Young love flourishes under German occupation, that sort of thing.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: But you’re not that young.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: (turns to Jan) Feisty and humourous, I like her. (back to Marie) Of course you can say no. (serious) Mrs Moravec saying you are trustworthy is one thing. But doing this could get you shot. (beat) You should think about that before -

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: (cutting in) My friend, Lenka. (beat) She sometimes couriers messages for Uncle Hajsky.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Good, so she knows how to keep her mouth shut as well? MARIE nods.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: We are going to a New Years Eve dance on Wednesday night. (beat) You would like to go? JOSEF looks at JAN. JAN shrugs. JOSEF turns back to MARIE and nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A smoky dance hall, softly illuminated in soft brown hues Tables and chairs around the edge of the floor. Some six so couples are dancing to a swing band. JAN and JOSEF stand at the bar. The atmosphere in the dance hall has an edge. It’s not relaxed and feels slightly surreal. Almost lost in time. Nervous looks. A banner hung across the hall proclaims “HAPPY NEW YEAR - 1942!" A few off-duty SS officers to one corner. Top buttons und red cheeks. But people avoiding them. A few whores flirt them. Upper class tuxedoes mixing with working class brown jack Business men mixing with artists and Black marketeer’s mi with Czech police. A group of friends drinking. One is quite drunk and start push a mate around. A few others step in and calm the situation down. Drinks and cigarettes are handed out. Ner looks in the direction of the SS officers. This is occupied Prague. The Dance hall has an a 1920's prohibition feeling to it and tonight being New Years eve temporary neutral ground for all attending, but only just

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: (to the crowd) Look at them... (beat) Going through the motions like some old ritual that no longer has any joy for them.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Maybe there is hope in the pretence... JOSEF lights a cigarette, he is a few beers in. Turns to JAN signals OFF SCREEN. MARIE and LENKA emerge through the crowd arm in arm. Both beautiful. Both receiving looks from various wannabe suit LENKA FAFEKOVA, like MARIE is elegant with striking red h she is slightly older but beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Looks like you fell on your feet with Lenka.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Stupid... JAN looks confused.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHROPOID V20
dialogues.text: The girls approach them.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Hello. Lenka, this is Jan and Josef. JOSEF turns his back on them. MARIE visibly disappointed. JAN smiles nervously at MARIE. Awkward pause.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: You know it’s not very polite to turn your back on a lady. JOSEF turns and talks but doesn’t look at them. He looks them.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: I'll pay you the compliment of being the two most beautiful girls in the room but this is not a night off for us.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Josef, maybe you are over-reacting a little. JOSEF gives JAN a look which silences him.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: (looking past Lenka and Marie) Me and Jan appreciate the effort but the point was not to attract attention. JAN looks over the room. A few people avert his gaze. Maybe JOSEF has a point.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: In future we need you to be as plain as possible. (beat) Think you can do that? MARIE nods, feeling small and rebuffed.

dialogues.speaker: LENKA
dialogues.text: You know, for most girls, a little lipstick is the only way to forget what is happening here. (beat) Even if it’s only for a few hours. JOSEF looks at the table with SS officers. One of them looking over. Observing while inhaling a cigarette. JOSEF now looks at Lenka for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Your lipstick gets you noticed and that gets us noticed and us being noticed could get us all shot. (beat) And now this little scene needs an ending. LENKA frowns, not understanding. JOSEF leans forward and whispers in her ear.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Slap my face so we can leave without suspicion. LENKA pauses for a second and understands the scene that needs to be played. She then hauls a slap across JOSEF’s right cheek. Her face plays the perfect part of a woman scorned.

dialogues.speaker: LENKA
dialogues.text: I’m not a whore! JOSEF rubs his cheek and sees: the SS officer turns and laughs with the others. The acted story, now clear, has averted any suspicion.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: (whispered to Lenka) Save your lipstick and pencilled stockings for when the war is over. JOSEF pushes past and leaves. JAN grabs his coat.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: (to the girls) I think that went well. Awkward beat and JAN follows JOSEF to the exit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A machine gun is placed on the table.

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: A British Sten Mark II machine gun. JAN and JOSEF inspect the weapon and clips as LADISLAV pl two anti-tank grenades on the table.

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: One hundred rounds. (beat) Model 73 anti-tank grenades with pencil fuses. (beat) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That's everything we could retrieve from the drop canister. JOSEF takes the Mark II Sten and sniffs the barrel.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: That smell reminds me of the training fields in Scotland! He throws the gun to JAN who catches it and takes a whiff

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Gun oil and turpentine - sometimes I think we drank it by the pint.

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: Uncle says he has made some progress with the information you asked for. (beat) There is a meeting at Café Slavia on Vodikova Street at 2pm, Tuesday.

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: You are still determined to go through with this? JOSEF looks down at the gun and then at LADISLAV. The sil confirming their stance. LADISLAV turns to leave.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: (to Ladislav and indicating the weapon) Ladislav, thanks. LADISLAV nods and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A late afternoon mist hangs in the air. The blackened spi of the churches and other buildings peek out from the mis like a dark fairy tale. People go about their business. People sit outside a café few nervously look around. No one can be trusted. Suspici rules the city. JOSEF is walking besides LENKA. Now she looks like a plai blonde in her late twenties. There is an awkward silence between the two. JOSEF looks over the street behind and sees: MARIE and JAN walking together on the side walk.

dialogues.speaker: LENKA
dialogues.text: I just wanted to apologise about Saturday night. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were completely right to do what you did. (beat) Marie didn’t fully inform me of the situation. (beat) She is young and still has romantic ideas about the war.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: And you?

dialogues.speaker: LENKA
dialogues.text: War is not romantic. JOSEF regards her for a second. She seems wise beyond her years - another by-product of war. JOSEF then looks acros the street. A man on the other side of the street in an overcoat and stands looking at them. JOSEF looks over his shoulder. Another man seems to be following them. JOSEF looks back at the first man who is now greeted by a woman and they start to walk off. Is he being unduly suspicious?

dialogues.speaker: LENKA
dialogues.text: We cross here. We are now walking with JAN and MARIE and we see JOSEF an LENKA cross the street a little up ahead.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: After our last date I thought you might both show wearing potato sacks... MARIE gives a shy smile.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Lenka was very angry that I didn’t tell her who you both were. (beat) I don’t know what I’m doing.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: You are doing fine. (beat) Its not your fault. (beat) It’s hard to see all the sides. (beat) Josef just has a knack for it.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: He must think me silly.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: I don’t. MARIE smiles. Her eyes lock with JAN’s. A sweet moment. Ahead, JOSEF and LENKA have now crossed the street and ar on the same side. They both enter a café. A man leans on the corner outside the café. Tooth pick in mouth, foot raised on the wall, relaxed but looking aroun JAN notices him. He must be a lookout for the Jindra Organization. JAN and MARIE pass him and into the café.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small neighbourhood café. Just a few locals. They look at JAN and JOSEF for a second before going back to their business. The PROPRIETOR behind the counter glances up at JOSEF and and indicates to them to go through a door at the back. JOSEF and JAN turn to LENKA and MARIE.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Take a seat here and order a drink. We won’t be long. MARIE and LENKA nod and sit down at a table. JOSEF and JAN walk through a doorway and into the back ro INT. SAFE ROOM, CAFE SLAVIA -— AFTERNOON 37 A grey modestly furnished flat at the back of the café. B JAN and JOSEF look round the room and see two other doors other than the one they entered. We recognize UNCLE HAJSKY and LADISLAV, head of the Jindr group from the first meeting. JAN and JOSEF turn and see three other men: Adolf OPALKA, Josef VALCIK and Karel CURDA. The men know each other and are happily reunited. Smiles, handshakes and slaps on backs.

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: I see you are no strangers to one another?

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: We all trained special operations together. (beat) (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valcik here was even on the same drop. VALCIK is a heavy set, handsome man with blonde hair.

dialogues.speaker: VALCIK
dialogues.text: Dropped ten minutes later and thirty miles off course!

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Glad to see you made it in one piece.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, please sit. JAN and JOSEF sit at the table and place their pistols in front of them. UNCLE HAJSKY and LADISLAV are also at the table, VALCIK a OPALKA sit to one side. CURDA in the background.

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: Thanks to Valcik and his group Silver A, we have finally reestablished communications with London.

dialogues.speaker: VALCIK
dialogues.text: I have orders to send and receive any communications between you and London. (beat) You have your own decoder paper, right? JOSEF and JAN nod to VALCIK.

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: Captain Opalka and Warrant Officer Curda have completed Operation Out Distance so both are now available to assist you. (beat) Captain Opalka is the senior officer here. OPALKA, early thirties, looks every inch the man you woul want as the captain of your team. Sharply chiselled face, determined manner. A natural leader.

dialogues.speaker: OPALKA
dialogues.text: This is true but your mission objective supersedes my rank. (beat) We had word from London. Anthropoid. Utmost priority. Assist with everything possible. (beat) This is your show, comrades.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHROPOID V20
dialogues.text: CURDA, a nervous man in his late twenties, looks over th meeting as UNCLE HAJSKY unfolds a map of Prague.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: You wanted to know everything we could find out about Heydrich. (indicating on map) We know he lives with his wife and children at a country chateau in Panenské Brezany and he has his office in Prague at Hradcany Castle. (beat) Both the chateau and the castle are heavily guarded and so are out of the question.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: What about trips to Berlin?

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: Probably once a month. He usually travels by train, we would know as the railway starts preparing the special carriages several days in advance.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: But the station and train will be heavily guarded.

dialogues.speaker: CURDA
dialogues.text: What about derailing the train outside of Prague? OPALKA looks at JAN and JOSEF. It’s not a bad idea.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: (looking at Josef) Blowing up a train?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: It’s a possibility. (to Valcik) Explosives?

dialogues.speaker: VALCIK
dialogues.text: That’s Curda’s department. Curda?

dialogues.speaker: CURDA
dialogues.text: I can get the explosives.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: What do we know about blowing up trains?

dialogues.speaker: CURDA
dialogues.text: I can show you. But basically You would need to blow the tracks and derail--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) We can derail the train, but that is no guarantee Heydrich is killed. (beat) I say we check his route between his home and the castle.

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: Uncle has made contact with an old student of his who works as a repairman at the castle. He is willing to help but can only provide us with the information of what time Heydrich arrives and what time he leaves the day after.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: What good is that?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: You can start to build a pattern of his routine. (beat) Some days he travels with an armed escort but some days he doesn’t. Maybe there is a pattern to this.

dialogues.speaker: CURDA
dialogues.text: This is going to take weeks!

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Then it will take weeks. We will only get one shot at Heydrich. After that security will be so tight that you won’t get an olive between him and us without making oil.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: I will rent a flat near the castle so the repairman can drop off the timetable from the day before on his way to work. (beat) Lenka or Marie can be there to collect them for us.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Good. We’1l check out the route he takes between the chateau and the castle.

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: (sliding them across) Your medical certificates. Work exempted, in case you are stopped.

dialogues.speaker: OPALKA
dialogues.text: (to Jan and Josef) What will you need?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: A camera with film, chemicals to process it and make prints. Binoculars, couple of bicycles, a torch and some red paint.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: (frowning at the request) That’s quite a shopping list, I’1l see what I can do. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: Part of Operation Out Distance was to re-supply the resistance with much needed cyanide capsules. (beat) We have lost so many of our people to the Gestapo and without the cyanide capsules many have talked - giving up valuable information into our operating procedures. OPALKA distributes the packets of glass vials of cyanide.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: In closing I just want to say to you all that this operation is involving almost everyone we have. (beat) In the event you are captured by the Gestapo you will have to face some harsh facts. There will be no escape. You will be tortured until you tell them everything you know. (beat) And then you will be executed. (beat) You must protect your fellow comrades and shut any links to them down, so carry the cyanide at all times. A heavy beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARIE and LENKA sit at the table drinking their coffee. A GERMAN MOTORBIKE with SIDECAR pulls up outside the Cafe The lookout from earlier throws down his toothpick and en the cafe. He strides up to the bar and presses the waiter bell three times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: UNCLE and LADISLAV react to the bell and the others follo suit.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHROPOID V20
dialogues.text: 40 JAN and JOSEF grab their pistols and JOSEF cracks the doo and the curtain to look into the Cafe. JOSEF’s POV: Two GERMAN soldiers stand at the bar behind lookout. Behind JOSEF, UNCLE opens the window to a side alley and starts to signal to CURDA to make an escape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The waiter places a coffee in front of the lookout and gi his attention to the lead German.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Cigarettes. The GERMAN SOLDIER #2 is looking at the photos of old Pra on the wall - this interest is leading him closer to the room. JOSEF sees him moving closer and turns to see CURDA going through the window but CURDA catches a flower pot with hi foot and the pot falls from the window sill and smashes i the alley outside. GERMAN SOLDIER #2 hears it and he walks towards the back room. JOSEF steals himself and takes one step away from the doo and aims his pistol. The German now on the other side of the door - reaches ou for the curtain. LENKA pushes her coffee cup from the table and it smashes the floor. Both the soldiers turn and look at her as she drops to on knee and starts to pick up the pieces. GERMAN SOLDIER #2 looks back at the door. On the other side of the door - JOSEF, JAN and the other like statues - guns at the ready. GERMAN SOLDIER #1 opens the pack as he looks down at LENK stockings as she suggestively finishes picking up the bro cup and places it on the bar. He lights the cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN SOLDIER
dialogues.text: (to German soldier #2 ) Kumpel, lass uns gehen! GERMAN SOLDIER #2 turns and walks back to his mate. GERMAN SOLDIER #1 drops some crowns on the bar and they leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men stand down and breathe a sigh of relief. INT. MORAVEC FLAT, MAIN ROOM —- MORNING 42 CLOSE UP of the wood that JAN has been whittling. JAN is using a filing tool. The wood is taking shape into the fo of the human figure. JOSEF and JAN sit on the sofa staring ahead. ATA is playi the violin in another room. MR MORAVEC is lighting up his pipe and chattering away (one gets the impression he woul chatter away even if he didn’t have an audience).

dialogues.speaker: MR MORAVEC
dialogues.text: (draws on pipe, billowing smoke) Out of Blue Boar tobacco!? Couldn’t believe it. I told him I'd been smoking it for twenty-odd years. Didn't have any. Says it’s because of the war. Didn’t believe that for a moment. (to Jan) Have you found work yet?

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Nothing concrete yet. But I think we have a plan.

dialogues.speaker: MR MORAVEC
dialogues.text: We have work down at the yard. (beat) You think perhaps you are too good to do such work?

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: No, Mr Moravec. It’s a kind offer. (beat) Maybe if what we have planned doesn’t work out? MR MORAVEC gives him a slightly suspicious look as he dra on his pipe. JAN and JOSEF help MRS MORAVEC to the kitchen with the breakfast plates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dishes are being piled in the sink.

dialogues.speaker: MRS MORAVEC
dialogues.text: (quietly to Josef and Jan) There are two bicycles downstairs for you. Both black, both ladies. Sorry, it was all I could get, I placed them there earlier. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hands Josef two leather cases ) A camera, loaded with film and binoculars. The other bits you asked for will be here tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POV through binoculars: The entrance to Heydrich’s chatea Panenské Brezany. Many armed German soldiers are in evide

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: As Uncle said, there are too many armed guards here. JAN has turned his bicycle upside down and is pretending fix a puncture. Josef lays hidden from sight in a ditch w his faced glued to the binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: (sneaking a sly look) Looks like there is a whole garrison there. HEYDRICH’s 3.5 litre Mercedes convertible sharks slowly o of the entrance. It’s being driven by his personal chauff Oberscharfiihrer KLEIN. The top is off and HEYDRICH sits the front.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Looks like our man. (beat) What’s the time?

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: (checks watch) Five minutes after nine. The Mercedes approaches them and roars past at sixty mile per hour. JAN busy with his tire and JOSEF digging deep to keep out sight.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Anything else coming?

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: No. Riding solo today. (beat) Oh, wait. An armed escort now roars past doing its best to keep up HEYDRICH but with no way of catching up.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Armed escort. (beat) Two minutes behind.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHROPOID V20
dialogues.text: 45 46 The armed escort races past. JOSEF gets up and dusts hims down.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: (retrieving his bicycle) If we can stop the Mercedes using a rope or steel cable across the road then two minutes would be all we need.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: (placing his bicycle the right way up) Even if the rope stops the car we need more than two minute to escape from here. We would have to deal with the armed guard here in the open. (beat) It would not be my first choice.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: And if it’s our only choice? Jan is silent.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: The point of the mission is to succeed.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: I’m more worried that we haven’t planned what to do if we are successful.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: What happens after is not important. JAN stares at JOSEF.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Just because London has given no information that extends beyond the mission objective doesn’t mean there shouldn’t be one. There is a long silence between them until finally:

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Let’s follow the route to Hradcany Castle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOSEF and JAN cycle down a street. Ahead there seems to b commotion. People in the street.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHROPOID V20
dialogues.text: 47 48 JAN and JOSEF come to a stop and dismount their bicycles. They push them through the people who stand and look up. of the people are emotional, others as still as statues. are mostly silent. German soldiers are very much in evidence. A German motor and side car. Soldiers with German shepherds that bark. JAN and JOSEF make their way through and then see what everyone is looking at. Continuing all the way to the end of the street are peopl hung from the street lamp posts by their necks. Signs han from their necks; “Traitor” - “Communist” - “Jew”. It’s a haunting site. Hell, seeping its way into the city JAN looks at JOSEF. They continue on in silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOSEF smokes a cigarette. Lost in thought. Looks around the cafe. Uncomfortable shuffles, averted looks. A knock on the glass window. JOSEF turns: It’s LENKA. JOSEF nods to her and she enters and sits opposite. They silently look at each other. LENKA has made an effor look plain but her natural beauty is easy to see.

dialogues.speaker: LENKA
dialogues.text: Do I look plain enough? JOSEF stubs out his cigarette in the ashtray and nods.

dialogues.speaker: LENKA
dialogues.text: Are you sure? (teasing) I can go rub some mud on my face if you would like?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: We have a tram to catch. Let’s go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LENKA and JOSEF sit side by side.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHROPOID V20
dialogues.text: 49 The other passengers avert eyes. The tram silent. Then co to a stop. JOSEF signals it’s their stop and they get off

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Busy street with workers starting to make their way home. JOSEF and LENKA walk and suddenly in front of them are fo German soldiers waiting around. JOSEF calculates it’s too late to cross the street withou looking suspicious so they walk past them. The soldiers stare at LENKA and a couple of them wolf whi and a few lewd comments are heard in German. Once past, JOSEF guides LENKA across the street to the co of Kirchmayerstrasse into Klein Holeschowitzerstrasse.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: I need to take some pictures. Will you be my model? LENKA smiles. JOSEF takes out the CAMERA from its case. It’s an old Rolleicord twin-lens reflex camera: LENKA stands in front of JOSEF. JOSEF frames the camera but it seems to be pointing at th street behind LENKA. She looks over her shoulder at the street and then back t JOSEF. JOSEF takes a picture and then winds the film.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: OK, one from over there. LENKA re-positions herself. JOSEF re-frames. Again the position of the frame seems to off to one side at the street corner behind her. CLICK. JOSEF winds the film. Re-positions the camera to t other side of LENKA where there is a waiting tram and CLI LENKA realises that JOSEF is shooting a reconnaissance of area and has no interest in taking her photo. Another CLICK and WIND. JOSEF now points the camera at LENKA. Her guard down. An honest moment. The real LENKA exposed for a fraction of a second. She is looking at JOSEF but almost off into the distance. JOSEF intuitively senses something in that mome and takes a picture.

dialogues.speaker: 52A
dialogues.text: 52 53 In EXTREME CLOSE UP we see the metal shutter and iris ope allowing the light onto the film. The mechanical shutter grunts and then snaps shut. EXT. PRAGUE CITYSCAPE —- DAWN 50 The black spires rise out of the dawn mist, eerie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HEYDRICH’s Mercedes pulls through the gates of the castle armed escort right behind. From a window above, the REPAIRMAN watches down as the ca enters the gates of the castle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A new dawn over the city as it slowly starts to wake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We follow a man from behind as he walks down the street. CLOSE UP of the man’s hand as he reaches into his jacket pocket and takes out a small envelope. He stops by a window of an apartment that looks out onto pavement and he knocks on the glass. The window opens and he hands the envelope to LENKA. He looks at her for a second. He is the REPAIRMAN. The REPAIRMAN’s POV through the window: he sees JOSEF and partly hidden by the blowing net curtains. The REPAIRMAN continues onto the castle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LENKA gives the envelope to JOSEF. He opens it. CLOSE UP on the contents: 9.15 - 5.15 With.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Arrived 9.15. Left at 5.15. With an armed escort. MARIE looks at LENKA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Armed escort? JOSEF looks at LENKA and then at JAN. Not sure how much t reveal.

dialogues.speaker: LENKA
dialogues.text: There is only one person in Prague that travels with an armed escort. MARIE looks slightly panicked.

dialogues.speaker: LENKA
dialogues.text: You're going to assassinate Heydrich?

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: What? Heydrich is the target?

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: For your own safety, it’s best you don’t ask too many questions.

dialogues.speaker: LENKA
dialogues.text: It’s a bit late for that, no?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: You agreed to help the resistance. Who the target is does not concern you.

dialogues.speaker: LENKA
dialogues.text: We are about to help you murder Reinhard Heydrich. Of course it concerns us!

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: OK, everyone just calm down. JAN leads MARIE to a seat at the table. Makes her sit.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Maybe it was a mistake not to inform you of the danger ...

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: (still reeling) Murder Heydrich?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Assassinate. (beat) Murder somehow implies he has a life worth living. On the table in front of LENKA is JOSEF’s pistol.

dialogues.speaker: LENKA
dialogues.text: You think I’m some little girl that is just here to follow the important parachutists around?

dialogues.speaker: 54B
dialogues.text: She takes JOSEF’s pistol and strips the clip, the top bar removes the chambered bullet and inspects the line, then resembles it. It all takes no more than six seconds. She stands and walks towards JOSEF where she hands him th gun.

dialogues.speaker: LENKA
dialogues.text: We have been resisting in our own way from the beginning. (beat) I personally don’t have any reservations killing a Nazi pig. (beat) But don’t treat us as though what you are about to do doesn’t affect us. (beat) It does and it will. (hands Josef his pistol) And you should keep your weapon clean. It’s filthy. JOSEF shares a look with JAN. They’ve been told.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOSEF places the camera on the table. Pours some chemicals into a measuring jug and then into a soup pot. Indicates to JAN to hit the light. The room goe dark and JOSEF takes the film from the camera and places in the pot.

dialogues.speaker: OK.
dialogues.text: JAN switches the light back on and JOSEF shakes the pot w looking at his watch. JOSEF places a light bulb into a pot of red paint. The negatives are processed and JOSEF inspects them under room light. Books are placed on top of one another forming two small towers. A 12x12 cm matte is cut from white card to be used as a printing easel. JOSEF removes the back of the camera and balances the cam between the books with the lens facing down and the open facing up.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHROPOID V20
dialogues.text: 55 56 The now red light bulb is screwed into the socket. JAN switches the main light off and JOSEF switches on the red bulb. The room bathed in red light safe for printing. The negatives are laid onto the open camera back and JAN holds a torch above to shine light through the negative. negative is projected through the lens and appears onto t board below. JOSEF turns the focus knob and a negative image comes int sharp focus on the printing easel - A home made enlarger. The torch is switched off and paper placed into the easel The torch is switched back on and then off for an exposur The printing paper is then placed into a frying pan fille with developing chemical and gently rocked. An image of a Prague street slowly starts to appear on th printing paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS MORAVEC is doing the dishes with MARIE doing the dryi In the background we hear ATA practicing the violin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAN and JOSEF sit looking through the photos that JOSEF t with the Rolleicord. Street of the route Heydrich takes to work everyday. On t edge of each photo is an out of focus LENKA. JOSEF takes a magnifying glass and studies the photos in minute detail. CLOSE UP of photo - The sharp turning from Kirchmayerstra into Klein Holeschowitzerstrasse.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: So, in the morning he approaches from that direction and then turns here to his right. (beat) It’s a pretty sharp turn. He would have to slow down quite a bit.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: It’s the slowest part of the whole route.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: (nods) We're not going to find anywhere better.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: (shrugs) Perhaps not perfect, but you’re right, nowhere better. They regard each other and are in agreement. JOSEF looks at the photos and sees the final photo he took of LENKA. stops him and he regards it for a second. JOSEF separates photo from the rest and places it in his wallet. JAN notices. JOSEF stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ATA stands in front of a music sheet stand practicing as JOSEF enters the room. JOSEF watches ATA perform. ATA finishes the piece and looks at JOSEF.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: I need to see Uncle. Can you let him know? ATA nods. MR MORAVEC enters the front door. He sees JOSEF talking closely to ATA and he sees ATA nodding in affirmation. ATA and JOSEF look over at MR MORAVEC. A moments pause an then JOSEF heads back to his room and ATA starts playing violin. MR MORAVEC looks concerned. INT. UNCLE HAJSKY’S RENTED FLAT —- MORNING 58 JAN sits whittling the wood and looking up inspects MARIE sits opposite trying to reassemble JAN’s pistol.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Breach over the lock. (beat) Slide and release. She completes the action.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: There you go. MARIE smiles at learning the action.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Tell me what London was like.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: (reminiscing) Me and Josef only went once. There was a blackout in place and then a Blitz raid. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The London Underground was used as air raid shelters and we spent the night there listening to the English sing their songs. There are three knocks followed by one knock on the windo JAN stops and MARIE goes to the window and opens it. The REPAIRMAN passes the envelope through. He looks past MARIE and locks eyes with JAN. JAN'’s POV of the REPAIRMAN is interrupted by the net cur blowing in the wind. The REPAIRMAN then leaves and continues to work. MARIE hands it to JAN. JAN switches his attention to the envelope. Opens it:

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: 9.17 - 4.42 Without. JAN writes it down on the sheet. We see that there is at least eight such entry times on the sheet. JAN runs his hands through his hair and exhales a frustra breath. MARIE looks at JAN.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: I don’t see any pattern. The start times are consistent but the armed escort seems to be pot luck. (beat) Some days yes, some days they’re on their own.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Are you really going to go through with this?

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: We have our orders.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: So you kill Heydrich. What then? You think there aren’t more like him? They come and the killing continues, even worse than it did before. (beat) When does it stop?

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: I wish I had an answer for you. You think any of this makes sense to me? (beat) Things used to be simple. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JAN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I worked at a paper factory. Clock in at eight, clock out at five. Wages on a Friday and a drink with the boys. A date on Saturday, go to the pictures on Sunday. (beat) Now I’ve been given orders to assassinate a high ranking SS officer that very few of us will have any chance of walking away from. MARIE holds a clenched fist to her chest as if in pain. JAN takes

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Then let’s walk away now. Let’s just leave.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: And go where, Marie? You think we can escape from what is happening? Pretend this madness is not real?

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Some days, I’m not even sure it is real. Heydrich chokes the people of this city with a blanket of fear. People shot for what? Their race? Their religion? Their cigarettes? (beat) And my father says we are lucky as the Germans need the Czech people and their factories to make armaments. (starts to cry) You hear the stories about Poland. her hand.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Shhh, Marie, it’s okay. They are suddenly very close, looking at one another.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: (searches Jan's eyes) We were taught ‘Thou shall not kill’ and yet here we are planning to kill someone. Just tell me we are doing the right thing. That two wrongs will somehow make a right? JAN searches her eyes for the longest time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PARK — DAY 59 JOSEF and LENKA walk through the mist covered park. The t seem like black statues.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHROPOID V20
dialogues.text: LENKA looks over JOSEF. New lines of stress have appeare his face.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: I think it’s my turn to apologize to you about the other morning. (beat) You were right to be angry. We should have told you what was at risk. (beat) To give you the choice to walk away.

dialogues.speaker: LENKA
dialogues.text: (ironic huff) Walk away? (beat) Opinions are divided as to what constitutes resistance. (beat) Many have got used to German rule. (beat) Many are just scared.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: But not you. LENKA’s turn to give JOSEF a silent glance.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: You know your way around a pistol.

dialogues.speaker: LENKA
dialogues.text: My father was a captain in the army. (beat) Wanted sons but got three daughters. (beat) He and many others were arrested in ‘39 when Germany took control of Czechoslovakia. (beat) When Heydrich first took power here last September, his first order was to execute all the prisoners.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: LENKA
dialogues.text: My father was among five thousand of the best military and academic minds shot in the first week by Heydrich. (beat) Afterwards, people started to call Heydrich the butcher of Prague. (beat) So, for me, there is no walking away, Heydrich is worth the risk.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHROPOID V20
dialogues.text: JOSEF give her a look. She, like many people, has lost a since the invasion of Czechoslovakia. LENKA nods. There is a man sitting on a bench reading a newspaper. JOSEF and LENKA sit on the bench next to him and we see i UNCLE HAJSKY. LENKA sits in the middle and JOSEF acts as if he is talki to LENKA but he’s actually talking to UNCLE HAJSKY.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: We have checked the route. (beat) We think we know how to do it.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: What will you need?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: We are going to need Opalka, Valcik and Curda.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: OK. I will arrange a meeting at the café the day after tomorrow, 3pm.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Our original contact address here in Prague was Oldrich Novak. Did you ever find out who had informed the Gestapo about him? UNCLE HAJSKY shakes his head no.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Who was his direct handler?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: Vanek Ladislav.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: And Ladislav? How long has he been part of the Jindra resistance?
