dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: He was one of the first.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: You trust him?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: (thinks) Yes. Why?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: He is one most opposed to what we have to do.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: He fears reprisals.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: From the Gestapo if he doesn’t inform them or from Jindra if he does? JOSEF stands and LENKA follows.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: (lighting a cigarette) When a man doesn’t want to rock the boat, you have to ask what is he afraid of? A long pause as UNCLE HAJSKY thinks about it.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: I’1l look into it. JOSEF and LENKA continue their stroll through the park.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOSEF and LENKA enter the flat. JAN and MARIE are nowhere to be seen. A soft clicking noise and we see a gramophone, the record finish, the needle catching. LENKA picks up the needle and looks at the record that wa playing. She smiles and puts the needle back to the begin of the record. JOSEF opens the door to the bedroom. JAN stands by the bed pulling his trouser braces over his shoulders, his shirt undone. MARIE is in the bed. She pul the sheets over her naked breasts. The music starts in the background.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Sorry. He closes the door and looks at LENKA. A brief moment passes before them before they both try an make themselves busy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Steam pours from a large antiquated coffee machine. JAN and JOSEF enter with LENKA and MARIE. The girls take seat at the table near the window.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHROPOID V20
dialogues.text: 62 JOSEF and JAN nod to the PROPRIETOR behind the counter as they go to the back room. INT. CAFE SLAVIA, SAFE ROOM — AFTERNOON 62 OPALKA, VALCIK are drinking cikorka. UNCLE HAJSKY and LADISLAV at the table. JOSEF and JAN join them. CURDA gua the curtain at the café doorway. JOSEF takes out a map of Prague and spreads it on the tab

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: We have checked every inch of his route from his home to the castle. (points at the map) Here... OPALKA checks the map.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Corner of Kirchmayerstrasse into Klein Holeschowitzerstrasse. OPALKA nods.

dialogues.speaker: OPALKA
dialogues.text: His car would have to slow down to take that corner.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Really slow down. (beat) He takes it at about 10 miles per hour.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: We've looked everywhere else and we think this is the only place it can be done.

dialogues.speaker: OPALKA
dialogues.text: (checks the area on the map) You have good exit routes. The busy street will add to the confusion and cover your escape.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: We averaged out all his morning arrival times and can expect him at approximately 9.30am.

dialogues.speaker: OPALKA
dialogues.text: Weapons?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: At that range? The Sten gun should hit everything within the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We also have two Model 73 anti-tank grenades. (beat) We may need more than the guns to stop the vehicle. The grenades can be rigged to explode on impact.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: And the armed escort? There is a slight pause. JOSEF looks at JAN.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: We have found no pattern for the armed escort. Some days he has it, some days he doesn’t.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Valcik, we are going to need a look out fifty yards up the road here. (taps the map) We will need an early signal to know if the armed escort is with him or not. VALCIK nods.

dialogues.speaker: OPALKA
dialogues.text: And if it is?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Then we stand down and await the next day.

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: Comrades, you know I have been against this action from the start. I can’t give the go-ahead without asking London to reconsider. Glances are exchanged between UNCLE HAJSKY and JOSEF.

dialogues.speaker: CURDA
dialogues.text: I’m with Ladislav. We should get London to rethink our position here in Prague.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: We have our orders.

dialogues.speaker: CURDA
dialogues.text: It’s easy for London to give orders - it’s our lives on the line...

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: (overlapping) Then at least wait for re- confirmation.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: It’s taken four months just to get this far. (beat) London needs action...

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: Then a few more days won’t make a difference. (looking to Valcik) Valcik? How long before you can get to the transmitter.

dialogues.speaker: VALCIK
dialogues.text: We can get to the transmitter the day after tomorrow. Then a couple of days for London to transmit back the answer.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: Then that is settled. Remain at the Moravecs’ place. I’1l contact you through Ata. Grave looks are exchanged from the divided men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close up of a birthday cake with 19 candles. Everyone congratulates ATA on his birthday. The cake is placed in front of ATA. He blows out the cand a moments darkness. Clapping and cheers - A brief mood of merriment within so much repression. MARIE turns on the lights of the living room. JAN, JOSEF, MARIE, LENKA, MR and MRS MORAVEC all present the cake is cut and distributed. Wine glasses show that all are relaxed and in good cheer.

dialogues.speaker: ATA
dialogues.text: Thank you! JOSEF raises a glass to ATA. JAN has his arm around MARIE and he looks slightly drunk he knocks back his glass of wine. He whispers something in her ear and then ‘tings’ his win glass with a tea spoon.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Ata, I know tonight is your party but I just wanted to make a little announcement.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHROPOID V20
dialogues.text: 64 JAN clears his throat and smiles at MARIE.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: I have asked Marie to marry me and she has said yes. More clapping and words of congratulations are spoken. JOSEF smiles but it fades to a dark look that he tries to cover. LENKA notices it, and JOSEF sees that she has seen it - l away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOSEF stands in front of a mirror shaving. Mind deep in thought. In the background JAN enters the room. He is drunk. Swayi JOSEF watches him in the mirror, the elephant in the room putting him off his shave. JAN regards him. JOSEF wipes his face with a towel and faces JAN.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: You know why we are here right? (beat) What we are about to do? JAN nods, eyes trying to focus on JOSEF as he processes t thought and regrettably nods.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Then what the fuck are you doing? JAN lost in thought, then a hopeful look at JOSEF.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Who is to say it won’t happen? (beat) London calls it off.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: They won't. (beat) We’re too close and London knows it. Jan starts to emotionally break a little. JOSEF steps forward and grabs the lapel of his jacket.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: You got to lock that away. (beat) I don’t want your emotions affecting your judgement and jeopardizing the operation.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHROPOID V20
dialogues.text: 65 JAN nods. Coming back to focus and putting on a brave fac

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: I have to think that there is a way through this. (beat) That when this is all over, there will be a normal life waiting for us. The way things used to be. (beat) Marie makes me feel that there is hope. (beat) I love her. JOSEF doesn’t have an answer. He has nothing similar that gives him strength other than the mission itself. Maybe h even a little envious that JAN has this. He releases his grip on JAN’s lapel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOSEF sits at the table. The Sten gun in 4 pieces laid ou before him. He is slotting the weapon back together BLINDFOLDED. He does it quickly placing the finished gun the table. JAN looks at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: 15 seconds but you didn’t add the gunstock. JOSEF removes the blind fold.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Lighter and smaller without it (beat) OK. I will try doing under my coat. LENKA and MARIE watch on as JOSEF takes the gun apart aga LATER and we see a series of close up shots of the Model anti-tank grenade being taken apart and replaced with new pencil fuses.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: The Model 73 is just too big. Sweat pours from JAN’s face as he concentrates on the explosive. JAN takes the explosive from the Model 73 and fits it int cout down water canteen and tapes it up with tape. He finishes the delicate work and slowly slides them across table.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Had the idea to transfer the Model 73 into water canteen for better portability. JOSEF seems impressed.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: (placing the finished item in front) Rigged for impact detonation.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Don’t drop them... JAN moves his hand and knocks one of the Model 73 grenade over, it rolls and falls off the edge of the table. JOSEF dives for it and catches it before it hits the grou JAN looks down at JOSEF on his back with amusement.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: That’s the empty one. They both start to laugh nerviously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAN, JOSEF, MRS MORAVEC and MR MORAVEC are sitting around crowded table. The meal is coming to an end. ATA enters and takes a seat. He sees his father lighting pipe and slides an envelope across the table towards JOSE

dialogues.speaker: ATA
dialogues.text: (whisper) From Uncle. JOSEF takes the envelope and nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOSEF opens the envelope and takes a piece of paper from The page full of letters like a letter puzzle. He holds it up to the light and JAN takes the DECODER PAP we saw earlier from under the bed and small book. JOSEF starts to decode the message. Looking at sentences book and counting the letters he starts to decode the message.

dialogues.speaker: A-N-T-H-R-O-P-O-I-D.
dialogues.text: (beat) P-R-O-C-E-E-D. S-T-O-P. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (beat) U-P-M-O-S-T. I-M-P-O-R-T-A-N-C-E.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Is that it? (beat) Nothing about getting us out afterwards?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: We complete the mission and await further instructions from London.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: London knows this is a probable suicide mission... A long pause between the men as they consider this. It’s interrupted by three sudden knocks at the front door. KNO

dialogues.speaker: KNOCK
dialogues.text: JAN and JOSEF grab their guns. Then:

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: It’s Uncle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOSEF opens the front door. UNCLE HAJSKY and LADISLAV sta there. They let them in. They look slightly panicked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men stand around the dining table.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: We have a problem. (beat) One of our spies within the Heydrich house has read a piece of correspondence that has ordered Heydrich back to Berlin. (beat) Within the household there have been conversations about a new posting to Paris. (beat) It means that after he leaves for Berlin he may not be back.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: When does he leave?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: 28th May.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHROPOID V20
dialogues.text: Panicked looks.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: That’s the day after tomorrow!

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: Tomorrow morning will be your only chance. (beat) After that he is gone for good. Looks are exchanged.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Then we have no choice. We do it tomorrow. LADISLAV takes a long look at UNCLE. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: Vanek here received a transmission from London.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: They agreed with my request to stand down the mission. He takes a piece of paper from his pocket and reads:

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: We believe we see the situation clearly, therefore, given the situation, any actions against officials of the German Reich do not come into consideration. Let Jindra group know. JAN looks hopefully at JOSEF.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Uncle gave us a coded message from London. Our mission has not changed. We are to go ahead as planned.

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: But this clearly states you must stand down.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: That message was not for us and we do not recognize it as a direct order to stand down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then at least wait for us to clarify it. It may have superceded your order.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: We do not have the luxury of time. After tomorrow Heydrich is gone.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: I have to agree with Josef. That transmission does not read like a direct order and I believe it was sent to settle nerves within the Jindra group. A long silence, then LADISLAV gathers his things.

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: I know you all doubt me. Suspect me of collaboration.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY LADISLAV
dialogues.text: Vanek... Please stop Uncle...

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: I know you've had me followed. (beat) I understand you don’t trust me but you have been planning this mission for the last five months. If I was an informer for the Gestapo, you think you would still be here? Do you?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Then why are you so against it? (beat) What are you afraid of? LADISLAV gives a huff with a shake of the head.

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: And Jesus asked him, “What is your name?” He replied, “My name is Legion, for we are many. (beat) What kind of retribution is fitting for the man that may be the devil himself. (beat) I fear Czechoslovakia will be wiped from the map. (beat) You ask me if I’m afraid? (beat) Yes, I’m afraid. A pregnant pause hangs in the air. LADISLAV turns on his heels and leaves, passing Mr. Morav as he enters the dinning room.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHROPOID V20
dialogues.text: 70 The raised voices have clearly woken Mr. Moravec from his sleep.

dialogues.speaker: MR MORAVEC
dialogues.text: What is going on here?

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry Mr. Moravec. Please go back to bed. A long tense moment.

dialogues.speaker: MR MORAVEC
dialogues.text: I know what you are planning to do. (beat) We are all resisting in our own way. But I must think of my family first. (beat) I would like you both gone from here after tomorrow. The men nod and Mr. Moravec finally leaves.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: (back to Uncle) We do it tomorrow morning. As planned.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: And if he has an armed escort? (beat) We can’t stand down and wait another day... A few tense looks.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Get word to Opalka, Curda and Valcik. If there is an escort then they can keep them busy but the first bullet has to be for Heydrich. (beat) Tell them to be on the corner at 8am. UNCLE HAJSKY gives a sad but reassuring smile.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: May God be with you. UNCLE HAJSKY and LADISLAV turn and leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOSEF places the weapons on a small table. JOSEF examines the Sten gun. He removes the stock to make shorter.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHROPOID V20
dialogues.text: JOSEF clears the chamber of the Sten, clocks it and rele the trigger. The hammer makes a hollow click. He dismantl it into 3 pieces and places it in a black bag, and then places some STRAW over the top to hide it.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: It’s tomorrow! ? JAN is pacing again like a caged animal. He is trying to breathe but the walls seem to be crashing inwards. Frustration of the uncertainty of what lays ahead. Panic attack fast approaching. Hyperventilating and muscle cram

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: It’s tomorrow! ? JOSEF goes to him but JAN pushes him away.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: (breaking down) I don’t want to die tomorrow. JOSEF grabs him and tries to restrain him. JAN resists. A vase is knocked from the side table and smashes on the fl JOSEF gets behind JAN and controls a slide down the wall until they are both sat on the floor. JOSEF behind JAN. MRS. MORAVEC comes in. JOSEF holds one hand up to her.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: It’s okay, it’s okay... MRS. MORAVEC looks worried but nods and leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Hey! Hey! Breathe! With me. (beat) Big breathe in. (beat) Big breathe out. Grabs a clip and a box of ammo from the table.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Here! Look, as we were trained. JOSEF loads a bullet into the clip.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Nice and easy. You do it. JAN starts to load a bullet in to the clip.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: That's it. Easy does it. And again. JAN loads another. The panic attack subsiding.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: There you go. (beat) It’s OK. Breathe, concentrate on the detail. It’s an incredibly tender and heart-breaking scene. We ha never seen JAN this vulnerable before and we have never s JOSEF this caring.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: I've shot at men in the field. (beat) Never killed one up close.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: We have a job to do. People are counting on us.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: If he does have an armed escort tomorrow...

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: We must send a clear message that we are not afraid. That Czechoslovakia is not afraid. (beat) Whatever the outcome for us, Heydrich must die. A pause. JOSEF nods his head. JAN looks into space for a second and then nods his head agreement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two beds on the floor. Soft moonlight bathes the room. A clock gently ticks. JAN and JOSEF’s eyes are wide open and staring up at the ceiling. Each lost in thoughts of the mission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A high-angled panoramic shot of the city of Prague.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAN and JOSEF enter the dining room with their coats and briefcases. MRS MORAVEC stands and begins to gather the dishes. ATA eats breakfast and MR. MORAVEC gives JAN and JOSEF a look.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHROPOID V20
dialogues.text: 74 75 Awkward silence. MRS MORAVEC takes the plates out to the kitchen. JAN follows her out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS MORAVEC starts to wash the dishes. She is suddenly aw that JAN is looking at her. They exchange a glance. JAN hands MRS MORAVEC the small figure he has carved in w MRS MORAVEC looks at the figure in her palm. CLOSE UP of the figure. It’s a wooden figure of a German officer. She suddenly understands, swallows hard. MRS MORAVEC then looks across to ATA who is wiping his pl with a crust of bread unaware of what has just taken plac but he must know. MRS MORAVEC places the figurine into the front pocket of pinafore and brushes some imagined crumbs from her dress. nods in confirmation. MRS MORAVEC leans on the counter for support. JAN, both silent. She looks at

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAN and JOSEF walk across the two bicycles are parked. They street and find LENKA waiting occupied and doesn’t take her JAN notices.

dialogues.speaker: MORNING 75
dialogues.text: street and to an alley where pull the bicycles into the there. She looks deeply pre- eyes off JOSEF. I'll wait for you up the street. JAN walks off and leaves LENKA and JOSEF facing each othe

dialogues.speaker: LENKA
dialogues.text: Uncle said we weren’t needed for a while. (beat) It’s today, JOSEF nods. A long pause hangs in the air

dialogues.speaker: LENKA
dialogues.text: Promise me - isn’t it? between the two of them.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHROPOID V20
dialogues.text: 76 She stops halfway through her sentence. She knows that no can promise anything in times like this. Their eyes locked. Time almost frozen. JOSEF steps forward and kisses her. His action quick. His body almost swallowing her up. And then he is gone. LENKA finds gravity again with a sound of expelled breath. JOSEF now striding off in to the distance. Doesn’t look b EXT. KIRCHMAYERSTRASSE —- MORNING 76 JOSEF and JAN cycle down the street. Ahead they see VALCI and OPALKA standing by a tram stop. JOSEF and JAN park their bicycles against a fence. The four men meet and light cigarettes as if they are jus normal men ready to start their day’s journey to work.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: (checking watch) We have plenty of time. 8.25. (beat) Where is Curda? OPALKA and VALCIK shrug. CURDA is missing.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: (lighting cigarette) Valcik, you take to the hill up there. (checking the sky) We have some sun so take this mirror. (beat) If he approaches without an armed escort then use it to signal this.

dialogues.speaker: VALCIK
dialogues.text: And if he does?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Then light a cigarette. (beat) When the car slows to take the corner I will step out and open fire with the Sten. My action will signal the attack. (beat) Jan, stand behind the attack point so you can throw the grenades at the armed escort if there is one. (beat) Opalka, when you see the car approach, try a slow walk across the street, see if you can slow him down even further before he takes the corner. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Opalka nods) Good luck. The men disperse to their agreed stations. JOSEF and JAN take a seat on a nearby bench. JOSEF takes parts of the Sten gun from the black bag and re-assembles them under his raincoat which is draped across his legs. VALCIK has taken up his position further along from where will get the first sight of HEYDRICH. He looks at his wat 9.05. OPALKA looks up towards VALCIK then across to where JOSEF JAN are sitting. JOSEF pulls the firing pin back on the Sten. The hollow s indicates that the weapon is cocked and ready.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: All good?

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Good. They both stand up. There is a moment between them. Everything has led to thi They give a nod. JOSEF nods and JAN turns towards his position further up Klein Holeschowitzerstrasse. JAN looks across to OPALKA and nods as several trams arri and disgorge passengers. A WOMAN passes pushing a pram. A MAN hobbles by on crutches. Two YOUNG LOVERS walk by hand in hand. A car honks its horn. A horse pulls a cart loaded with scrap metal. This is Prague, a living city. On the verge of a major ev JOSEF and JAN look up to VALCIK waiting for a signal. JAN looks at his wristwatch: 10.10. JAN looks over to JOSEF who gives a shrug. JAN looks down. His hand starts to shake uncontrollably. grabs his wrist and tries to stop it. His breathing is he

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: (to himself) Breathe, as we were trained...

dialogues.speaker: ANTHROPOID V20
dialogues.text: He looks up. VALCIK at the top of the street suddenly turns and gives signal, a mirror flashing the reflection of the morning s across the faces of JAN and JOSEF. HEYDRICH is approachin and without an armed escort! JOSEF steps out to the corner of the street with the Sten concealed under his draped coat. JAN opens the brief case and grabs a grenade ready to thr Two trams come to a halt on the opposite side of the road HEYDRICH’s Mercedes speeds over the hill and down Kirchmayerstrasse. JAN looks at the Mercedes as it starts to slow down. JAN’s POV: As OPALKA crosses the street in front of the Mercedes. The Mercedes breaks and sounds its horn at OPAL JOSEF sees the Mercedes approaching him and the turning. JAN'’s POV of the Mercedes approaching JOSEF and the turn JOSEF steps into the road. The Mercedes is now only sever yards away as it approaches him. JOSEF throws off the coat covering the Sten gun, raises i and aims at HEYDRICH who is sitting in the open front passenger seat. HEYDRICH’s POV. JOSEF looming ahead, Sten gun in hand. JOSEF has the target in point blank range. A sure thing. Time slows down. JOSEF pulls the trigger. “CLICK”. It is a single hollow sound that comes from the Sten gun.

dialogues.speaker: IT HAS JAMMED
dialogues.text: JOSEF pulls the trigger again... “CLICK”. IN SLOW MOTION and IN CLOSE UP JOSEF re-cocks the firing A piece of STRAW is seen caught within the breach. “CLICK”.

dialogues.speaker: KLEIN
dialogues.text: (Heydrich's driver) Scheisse! HEYDRICH sees this and immediately grabs his pistol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Halten das auto! HEYDRICH stands up with his pistol and aims at JOSEF. JAN’s POV of HEYDRICH standing aiming his pistol at the frozen JOSEF. JOSEF pulls at the trigger again - “CLICK”.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: (screams )

dialogues.speaker: RUN
dialogues.text: JAN steps forward and throws a grenade at the Mercedes. JOSEF throws down the Sten and stares down the barrel of HEYDRICH’s gun.

dialogues.speaker: BOOOOM
dialogues.text: JAN'’s grenade explodes at the rear of the vehicle. The blast throws up a shower of fragments from the car so of which hit JAN in the face. From inside a nearby tram, the blast from the bomb shatte all the windows showering the passengers with glass. Ther are shouts and screams from the dazed and frightened passengers. An angle from within the tram. We see the driver KLEIN fi his pistol at JAN. JAN's escape is blocked by a now crowded road. Blood pour from a cut above his eye. He fires shots into the air to clear a path through. He mounts his bicycle and pedals of furiously. Behind him VALCIK has pulled a pistol and fires two shots KLEIN. KLEIN ducks and returns four shots. One hits VALCIK in the thigh and he goes down. KLEIN then turns and sees: JAN getting away on the bicycle. KLEIN steps forward and fires two shots. But JAN is covered by the crowd and two of them get caugh the cross fire. A clear path opens up for KLEIN and a good shot at JAN is lost as JAN disappears round the corner of a building. HEYDRICH is now out of the car and is holding his pistol, he is in great pain. He has been hit somewhere.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHROPOID V20
dialogues.text: 77 HEYDRICH staggers towards JOSEF and fires several shots a him. The shots are returned by JOSEF from behind a telegr pole. HEYDRICH then collapses as KLEIN appears beside him. JOSEF fires two quick rounds but they miss KLEIN and HEYDRICH. KLEIN runs at JOSEF firing his pistol. JOSEF runs up the hill with KLEIN in pursuit. KLEIN goes fire at JOSEF but his gun is empty. JOSEF fires a couple of shots back at KLEIN but fails to him. VALCIK is back up and attempting to run from the scene wi bad limp. HEYDRICH is slumped against the side of the car. Pale. Laboured breathing. The CAMERA TRACKS OFF him and TRACKS the passenger seat. A hole has been blown through the sea and its horse hair stuffing is exposed. Blood slowly drip from the horse hair. Drip, drip, drip... Reaching the bottom of the hill JOSEF sees a butcher’s sh and hopes he can find refuge there. He runs towards it. INT. BUTCHER’S SHOP - MORNING 77 A small shop with the BUTCHER cutting meat on a block. JO rushes in and the BUTCHER is immediately alarmed by his presence and attempts to throw him out. JOSEF points his Colt semi-automatic at him and the BUTCH runs out into the street. JOSEF goes through to the back of the shop and finds that there is no rear entrance. He returns to the front of the shop and looks out. POV through the shop window - JOSEF sees the BUTCHER talk to KLEIN and gesticulating towards his shop. Time is running out for JOSEF. He must act soon. He runs the shop gun aimed. He has caught KLEIN unawares. KLEIN raises his gun and fires but JOSEF is quicker and shoots at him twice, hitting him in the leg and hip as KL drops to the ground. JOSEF runs out down the street and into an alley.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOSEF emerges from the alley and runs for a moving tram. catches up and jumps on board. INT. TRAM —- MORNING 79 JOSEF is out of breath. He moves up the tram and takes a seat. He throws a few nervous glances around the tram but nobody seems to be paying him any attention. The tram gains distance from the chaotic scene behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tram comes to a stop and JOSEF steps off. He looks around trying to get his bearings and sets off i northerly direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As JOSEF approaches the building he sees CURDA waiting outside. He seems greatly agitated.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Where were you Curda?

dialogues.speaker: CURDA
dialogues.text: I didn’t think you were really going to do it. JOSEF grabs him by the collar, looks like he is going to smash his face in.

dialogues.speaker: CURDA
dialogues.text: It’s all over the radio. (beat) You shot him?! JOSEF clenches his jaw in anger and then releases him.

dialogues.speaker: CURDA
dialogues.text: The radio said that 20,000 SS troops have been drafted in to look for us. (Beat) I have to get my family out of Prague.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: No one is going anywhere. You try and flee now they will pick you up before you get to the city limits. Go back to your family, batten down the hatches and stay calm. Stay out of sight and keep your mouth shut. Think you can do that? (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (off Curda's nod) Now get out of my sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOSEF enters. JAN is already there. He is sitting on a bench as MRS MOR treats his wounds with iodine. JAN is weakened and greatl agitated. Did they or did they not succeed? A heavy silence hangs in the air between them. JOSEF slowly shakes his head in utter disbelief of the ev that have just happened. JOSEF loses it and swipes some tins of food off a shelf.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: He was definitely wounded.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: KURVA! The Sten gun! That bloody Sten gun! (beat) I had him! JOSEF points an invisible Sten gun into space. His imagination reliving the moment.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: (softly imagining) I bloody had him... (then angry)

dialogues.speaker: HE WAS RIGHT THERE
dialogues.text: MRS MORAVEC finishes attending to JAN’s face and stands, putting away her things. Silence hangs heavy in the room.

dialogues.speaker: KNOCK
dialogues.text: JAN and JOSEF sit bolt upright and grab their guns. Then a single KNOCK! JAN opens the door a crack, pistol aimed. JAN's POV: we see UNCLE HAJASKY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three men and MRS MORAVEC sit around talking in hushe tones.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: What went wrong out there? JOSEF stares into space, dejected. SIRENS are heard outside. JAN looks out the window from behind the curtains. JAN'S POV: a street scene with German soldiers marching, several German vehicles, sirens screeching. JAN turns from the window.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Looks like the whole of Prague is crawling with Germans.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: It was to be expected.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: We didn’t even kill him!

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: Wounded.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: How bad?

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: (shrugs) It is hard to say. The SS still have the hospital surrounded so, presumably, he’s still alive. The Germans have more men and guns up there than they have on the Eastern front. UNCLE HAJSKY goes to the radio and switches it on. German heard, followed by the Czech translation.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO ANNOUNCER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Karl Frank has temporarily taken Heydrich’s place and has proclaimed a state of emergency and a curfew. (beat) A reward of ten million crowns will be given to any information that leads to the arrest of the criminals. (beat) Anyone caught aiding the criminals will be shot with his entire family. UNCLE HAJSKY switches it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All radio stations are transmitting the same message continually. JAN gives MRS. MORAVEC a concerned look.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: Nothing is leaving or entering Prague. (beat) The bicycle you used has been found. It has blood upon it. Also your briefcases. The Germans have put these in the window of the big Bata shop in the city centre to see if anyone recognises them. (beat) They’ve also taken several thousand hostages and are shooting people in the street. (beat) All home owners must declare to the police all persons staying with them who have not already been reported. (beat) Failure to do so will be punishable by death. (beat) What this means to you is that you can no longer remain here. There are no safe houses left any more. MRS MORAVEC and UNCLE HAJSKY share a look.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Where do we go?

dialogues.speaker: MRS MORAVEC
dialogues.text: I’ve asked Father Vladimir Petrek, he is the dean of the Orthodox Church.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Where is he going to hide us? In heaven?

dialogues.speaker: MRS MORAVEC
dialogues.text: The cathedral of Saints Cyril and Methodius.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: He has agreed to hide all the parachutists until we can return you to London. JOSEF gives JAN a look.

dialogues.speaker: MRS MORAVEC
dialogues.text: I’ll pack you some warm clothes and blankets.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHROPOID V20
dialogues.text: 85 86 87 88 JAN and JOSEF nod and the men shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: Rest here tonight. I will be back to pick you up first thing in the morning. UNCLE HAJSKY leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOSEF wakes to the sound of HYSTERICAL CRYING coming from room next door. He wakes JAN and places a finger to his mouth as a signal They grab their pistols and flank the door. INT. MORAVEC FLAT, MAIN ROOM —- MORNING 86 JAN and JOSEF enter the main room and see MRS MORAVEC consoling MARIE. MARIE looks up and sees JAN. Goes to him. Slumps into his arms.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: What is it? MRS MORAVEC looks from JAN to JOSEF. Sadness in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MRS MORAVEC
dialogues.text: It’s Lenka.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NO SOUND - MARIE exits the tram and sees LENKA down the street. CLOSE UP - LENKA smiles at MARIE and waves. To the side, German soldiers pour out of two trucks and s to round people up. The expressions on MARIE’s and LENKA’s face instantly cha LENKA is cut off from MARIE. LENKA looks around. She turn her heels and starts to walk fast to try and get away fro the madness.

dialogues.speaker: MRS MORAVEC
dialogues.text: The Germans were rounding up random hostages off the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LENKA’s walk suddenly turns into a run. The CAMERA just i front of her and keeping up with her. The sound of her breath. In the background we can hear a German screaming HALT! An intense sound building until:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Loud machine gun fire makes MARIE jump and she covers her mouth with her hand.

dialogues.speaker: CUT BACK TO
dialogues.text: INT. MORAVEC FLAT, MAIN ROOM —- MORNING 92

dialogues.speaker: MRS MORAVEC
dialogues.text: She was shot trying to escape. JOSEF closes his eyes. For a second we see LENKA’s hair gently blowing in the wi in slow motion. LENKA’s dead hand hanging limp. Blood dripping from the finger tips. Back with JOSEF. Anger on his face. He looks at MARIE. MARIE’s face puffy from crying. Her eyes scared. He strides off to their room. JAN follows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOSEF collecting his weapons. Loading them. Cocking them. JAN enters the room and sees what he is doing.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Josef! (beat) Josef! Stop! JOSEF makes to leave and JAN blocks his path.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Out of my way.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHROPOID V20
dialogues.text: 94 95 JOSEF tries to push past but JAN grabs him. The two of th suddenly in a fight. Fists are thrown and blocked. They grapple until a stale mate is found, both men breathing h

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Josef, listen to me. (beat) What if they take you alive? (beat) You are risking everyone that has helped us and for what? To shoot a few soldiers? (Josef struggles against Jan's grip) STOP! SHE’S GONE!

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: It’s all my fault. (beat) I tried to kill Heydrich (beat) But I killed her!

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: It’s not your fault. JOSEF breaks down and starts to cry. JAN holds him.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: (softly) I'm sorry... JOSEF sobs into JAN’s shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A clock ticks. MRS MORAVEC, ATA, MARIE, JAN and JOSEF sit stand in the room in silence - waiting. Three knocks then knock at the front door. ATA goes and lets in UNCLE HAJSKY.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: It’s time... MARIE hugs JAN. She doesn’t want to let go. JOSEF stands in front of MRS MORAVEC. Both their eyes red His emotions break through for a second as he moves forwa and hugs her. A tear runs down her face. Last looks and JAN and JOSEF leave with UNCLE HAJSKY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A flurry of action as German army trucks unload soldiers. People are stopped on the streets. Distant gun shots are heard.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHROPOID V20
dialogues.text: 96 97 Several streets. Various angles as JOSEF and JAN follow U HAJSKY at a discreet distance from one another. They foll him towards their new hiding place. German soldiers are greatly in evidence. Loud speakers ec instructions regarding the curfew now in place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: UNCLE HAJSKY stops and waits for JOSEF and JAN to catch u with him.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: This is the cathedral of Saints Cyril and Methodius. Go through that entrance. Father Petrek will greet you. (beat) Ata will be bringing you food. (beat) Ladislav is working with London on your exit plan. (beat) I know this maybe is not what you want to hear at present but... (beat) I regret nothing. You are two of the bravest men I have ever met. A pause between the men and then UNCLE HAJSKY leaves. JOSEF and JAN watch him leave and then turn towards the cathedral. [NOTE: Hereafter the Cathedral of Saints Cyril and Method is referred to as just the CATHEDRAL. ]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The magnificent main part of the cathedral with the altar the end. A balcony high above runs around the nave. JOSEF and JAN enter the cathedral and stand in admiration looking at the fittings and decorations. They both cross themselves. The silence weighs heavily upon them. Footsteps are heard. FATHER (Vladimir) PETREK approaches. is a tall angular man with deep set eyes, a moustache and goatee beard. He is in his early fifties. He has a gentle direct manner.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER PETREK
dialogues.text: I am Father Petrek. Welcome. (beat) Please follow me. FATHER PETREK leads them to the side of the entrance wher raises a carpet to reveal a two feet square flagstone wit metal ring in the centre. JAN pulls up the flagstone ‘doo It reveals a ladder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is our ‘hidden’ crypt. You will be safe there. He ushers them down.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER PETREK
dialogues.text: I have to go now.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Thank you, Father.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: Yes, thank you, Father.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER PETREK
dialogues.text: Until later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOSEF and JAN descend the steps into the crypt. 98 The crypt measures some fifty by twelve feet and is aroun ten feet high. It is made of stone. There are square-shap niches in the wall where coffins were once placed. At som time in the past the coffins have been removed and the ni became ossuaries. At the bottom VALCIK limps over with OPALKA to greet them

dialogues.speaker: VALCIK
dialogues.text: You made it!

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: What happened to your leg?

dialogues.speaker: VALCIK
dialogues.text: Was caught in the crossfire. Just a scratch. There is a solemn air to their reunion.

dialogues.speaker: OPALKA
dialogues.text: I’m sorry it wasn’t the outcome we all hoped for.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: None more than us... Then three other members of the resistance, SVARC, BUBLIK and HRUBY appear. Introductions and greetings are exchang

dialogues.speaker: OPALKA
dialogues.text: (to Josef and Jan) This is Svarc, Bublik and Hruby. They are from the airdrops this spring. (beat) Boredom may be the biggest enemy we have here. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: OPALKA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m suggesting three men on guard duty in the nave balcony at all times. (beat) We rotate every six hours. All of the men nod their heads.

dialogues.speaker: OPALKA
dialogues.text: Bublik, Svarc, come with me. We'll take first watch. JOSEF and JAN begin clearing their living spaces in the w niches. JAN continues clearing out the bones. He stops for a mome and looks up. High on the wall is a rectangular opening o the street, measuring about five foot by one, the only ventilation for the crypt. We hear the sound of a loud speaker echoing a looped mess in both Czech(English) and German.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Germans put up reward signs and appeals for informati all over Prague. Leaflets are given out in the street. Th appeals are in shop windows. People are interrogated in t street, beaten, marched off, arrested. The bicycle, coat and brief case that was used in the assassination attempt are displayed in the Bata shop wind There is a sign in the window. It reads: Reward of 10,000,000 Crowns 1. Who can provide information on the Criminals? 2. Who saw them at the scene of the crime? 3. To whom do these objects belong? Whoever is able to provide this information and who fails do so voluntarily will be shot with his family. Furthermore, from May 28, 1942, all owners of houses, apartments, hotels, etc, in the Protektorate must declare the police all persons staying with them who have not alr been reported. Failure to do so will be punishable by dea ss—Obergruppenfuhrer Chief of Police K. H. Frank.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHROPOID V20
dialogues.text: 100 101 102 It’s no small amount. The crowd outside the shop window hustle to see the items used in the attack. Amongst them we catch sight of a man looking at the items People cross the frame and obscure him but the CAMERA is tracking in and he starts to fill the frame. The line of sight is now clear of people and we clearly see who it is It’s CURDA. INT. CATHEDRAL - DAY. ATA enters the Cathedral carrying a basket and crosses himself at the alter. He then goes to the confession box enters. The central partition opens and we see JAN.

dialogues.speaker: ATA
dialogues.text: (indicating the basket) I brought you food.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Thanks Ata. The empty basket is under the bench in there. (beat) Have you seen Marie? ATA shakes his head no.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Can you get a message to her? I need to see her. ATA nods. He leaves with the empty basket the same way he entered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAN is standing upon a small wooden ladder and peering ou the rectangular opening high up on the wall. JAN's POV: A crowded busy street. Many Germans in evidenc INT. CATHEDRAL, CARETAKER’S OFFICE - DAY 101 On guard duty, OPALKA wanders into the caretaker’s office takes a look around. A filing cabinet. OPALKA opens the top drawer and takes a look. In the second drawer he takes a file. Inside are th plans of the church. He holds them up to the light and st to study them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OPALKA and HRUBY stride up to the end of the crypt. JAN a JOSEF are on lookout.

dialogues.speaker: OPALKA
dialogues.text: (pointing) Beyond this brickwork and masonry there is a large main sewer that empties into the river.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: How do you know?

dialogues.speaker: OPALKA
dialogues.text: I found some plans in the caretaker’s office. (beat) If we can chisel through this Masonry and get to the sewer we have a means of escape if we need it.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Escape to where?

dialogues.speaker: OPALKA
dialogues.text: Until the British send plans for our rescue we are stuck here. (beat) Should we be discovered here then there is no way out. I would like us to have this option. (beat) We would then take our chances on the streets. JAN, JOSEF and the others nod. It’s a good plan.

dialogues.speaker: OPALKA
dialogues.text: Two of us will be working here at all times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOSEF, JAN and OPALKA are on the balcony. They are all be columns but with a clear view down the entire length of t cathedral. There are footsteps across the church floor. They look an see it’s FATHER PETREK. He takes the stairs up to the balcony. They greet an out of breath FATHER PETREK at the top.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER PETREK
dialogues.text: I have news. A long pause as the men await the news.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER PETREK
dialogues.text: Heydrich died yesterday in the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: You sure of this?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER PETREK
dialogues.text: Yes. The Germans have announced this. Preparations are under way for a state funeral. The body is to be sent back to Berlin. Another pause.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER PETREK
dialogues.text: Finding those responsible for this act may be occupying the Reich more than winning the war at the present time. JAN and JOSEF look at one another. A brief moment passes between them. They got Heydrich, eventually.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The coffin of Heydrich is being transported to Berlin. Th coffin draped in a black SS flag. Flames from lit torches each corner. Two SS guards stand on watch. Eerie, like a spell being cast by the forces of the dark arts. [NOTE: T will be a recreation of the actual footage.] The sound of train on the tracks turns into chisels against masonry. SOUND OVERLAP of chisels against masonry...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the crypt. JAN and JOSEF hammer away at the masonry li men possessed. Then VALCIK and BUBLIK take over. It’s lik relay race. Sweat pouring from JAN’s face as he looks over to JOSEF w heavy breaths. They share a look and then JAN looks up at morning light streaming through the street level slit. They swap over again. OPALKA calls down from the small hole in the ceiling,

dialogues.speaker: OPALKA
dialogues.text: Jan! Someone to see you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAN climbs out of the crypt to see MARIE. A moment then MARIE rushes forward and embraces JAN. They hold each other for a moment. They pull away and MARIE ha tears of joy. They joy fades and she looks terrified.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: How long will you stay here?

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: There is talk of getting us back to London. (beat) When this is all over, I will come back for you.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: Back for us both. She places JAN’s hand onto her belly. JAN computes, sudde overjoyed.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Really? MARIE nods. A moment of joy that MARIE is still frightene let surface.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: I’m so scared. Everyone is scared. (beat) Yesterday the Germans went to a village to the north-west of Prague called Lidice and shot every man over the age of sixteen. The women and children have been taken to camps and the buildings were razed to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: But why Lidice? It makes no sense.

dialogues.speaker: MARIE
dialogues.text: There has been talk that the village aided you somehow. (beat) What kind of World is it to bring a child into?

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: It will not always be like this. (beat) One day, it will be different, like how it once was... (beat) This I’m sure of. JAN searches her eyes and scoops her up in his arms once again. Two lone figures in the empty church. The sound of Hammering continues from the crypt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A meeting. The seven men plus FATHER PETREK. JOSEF and JAN are gravely shocked. Tears appear in their eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: (sadness) We have never even been to Lidice.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER PETREK
dialogues.text: These are dangerous times. Mere gossip wipes a whole village from the face of the earth. (beat) Today Karl Frank issued an amnesty broadcast. A full pardon for any person and their family in exchange for any information known about the assassins. Even if they did not come forward before. But there is a deadline of five days, after that, they plan to execute 30,000 Czechs.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: This must stop!

dialogues.speaker: OPALKA
dialogues.text: And what do you propose? JAN thinks for a minute and anger flits across his face.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Josef and I will go to a park... Place placards around our necks saying we killed Heydrich... (beat) -+-and commit suicide. There is a physical reaction from the men to this suggest and OPALKA steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: OPALKA
dialogues.text: This is stupid talk. Stupid talk! As soldiers it is your duty to stay alive and continue fighting. Do you understand that? I will not hear such stupid talk again. JOSEF and JAN are chastened.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER PETREK
dialogues.text: The responsibility does not rest with you. We know who is responsible. They will have to answer...eventually. And they will. (beat) If I didn’t believe that I would not be here now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOSEF and VALCIK sit up in the balcony on guard duty. JOSEF takes the photo of LENKA from his wallet and looks it. Deep from within the crypt the faint sounds of stone being chiselled by a hammer.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHROPOID V20
dialogues.text: 105 106 107 108 109 113 JOSEF wipes the photo clean with his thumb when the sound a truck suddenly makes him look out onto the street. A German army truck pulls up and several soldiers jump ou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the crypt, OPALKA and BUBLIK hammer away at the masonr Thousands of hammer and chisel blows scarcely make an impression on the hard masonry. JAN is up a ladder. He peers out of the slit that leads t the street. JAN'’s POV: German truck and several soldiers walking tow the church. JAN signals to OPALKA and BUBLIK to stop work. JAN looks back to the street. The German soldiers make th way into the church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOSEF and VALCIK look down and see the German soldiers en the church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rest of the men, guns at the ready, stare upwards as sounds of the German boots echo out across the church flo above them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POV: the German soldiers carrying out a cursory search of church. They shrug and leave the way they came in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAN'’s POV through the slit as the German soldiers climb in the truck. A few more soldiers who had been searching across the street return as well. All board the truck tha starts up and drives off. The men all look at each other and sigh a big sigh of rel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXTREME CLOSE UP of a mans face. He is HANS MULLER. A Ger who speaks Czech. He wears glasses and a piece of paper i reflected in them.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHROPOID V20
dialogues.text: 114 NOTE: THE CAMERA NEVER LEAVES HIS FACE.

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: You say you know the men who assassinated Reichsprotektor Reinhard Heydrich but you did not take part in it. He looks up and OFF SCREEN to give a signal and looks bac down the report. As he continues to read we hear footstep and then someone being punched to the floor, a chair cras to the floor and we hear the person being kicked.

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: You say you don’t know where they are but you know the family who sheltered them. The sound of the man being lifted back on the chair cough and spluttering. Same as before, he looks up and OFF SCREEN to give a sign and looks back down the report. As he continues to read w hear footsteps and then someone being punched to the floo a chair crashes to the floor and we hear the person being kicked.

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: You say don’t know where they are but you know the family who sheltered them. The sound of the man being lifted back on the chair.

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: (Looking at the person) You walked in here on your own accord to give us this statement. (reading from the report) You say you are a true patriot and the reason for doing that is because you want to protect your family and for the killing of innocent Czechs to stop. We finally cut to the reverse and we see a man sitting opposite the desk with his head bowed. He slowly starts t raise his head as the CAMERA PUSHES IN.

dialogues.speaker: MULLER
dialogues.text: And you say your name is Karel Curda. CURDA looks up, his face beaten and swollen. He nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Early morning. Silence in the apartment aside from the plaintiff sound of ATA’s violin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MS of the front door to the apartment. Silence aside from ATA’s violin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six Gestapo officers stand in silence around the entrance the Moravec apartment building. Four bear machine guns, t other two pistols. An officer with a pistol nods to the four with the machin guns. They are to ascend the stairs now. They carry out t order in silence. INT. MORAVEC FLAT, ATA’S ROOM —- EARLY MORNING 117 ATA practices on his violin in his pyjamas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Gestapo officers ascend the stairway in silence. A do appears and starts sniffing around them. They pause. Then dog scurries off. They continue their ascent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A closer shot of the front door. INT. MORAVEC FLAT, ATA’S ROOM —- EARLY MORNING 120 ATA pauses and studies the music score on his practice st

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Gestapo officers are now arrayed around the front doo the Moravec apartment. They wait in silence. A plain clothes senior Gestapo officer, FLEISCHER, 30s, v thin and lugubrious looking tries the door. It is locked. steps back and nods to an officer with a machine gun. The officer steps forward and takes aim at the hinges.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MS of the front door. ATA has resumed his violin practice Two loud bursts from the machine gun shatter the silence. door hinges are destroyed and the door partially splinter The door is then kicked in. The armed officers rush into apartment shouting and bellowing. They spray out into different rooms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS MORAVEC comes into the lounge from the kitchen and tw officers immediately grab her. INT. MORAVEC FLAT, ATA’S ROOM —- EARLY MORNING 124 ATA is going towards the door of his room when it bursts and two of the officers rush in and grab him violently, h violin falls to the floor and is trampled upon as they dr him out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ATA is pushed next to MRS MORAVEC in the middle of the lounge. MR MORAVEC is also bundled in. MR MORAVEC stops for a second in front of his wife. An accusing stare on his face. MRS MORAVEC meets his gaze but can’t hold it for long. Wi tears in her eyes she looks away. MR MORAVEC is pushed and they are lined up facing the wal with their hands in the air. A man in his late forties is brought in from outside. He removes his hat as a sign of respect. His name is Josef CHALUPSKY and he is a Czech interpreter who speaks German MRS MORAVEC is grabbed from the wall and turned to face FLEISCHER and CHALUPSKY.

dialogues.speaker: FLEISCHER
dialogues.text: (loudly, menacingly) Wo sind die fallschirmspringer?

dialogues.speaker: CHULUPSKY
dialogues.text: Where are the parachutists?

dialogues.speaker: MRS MORAVEC
dialogues.text: I know nothing. You must be confusing us with other Morav... FLEISCHER cuts her off in mid-sentence as he punches MRS MORAVEC square in the face with a sickeningly accurate bl MRS MORAVEC hits the floor hard. ATA screams but is retra and gagged with his own belt.

dialogues.speaker: FLEISCHER
dialogues.text: (to the other officers) Stehen sie auf. MRS MORAVEC is pulled up by two officers. MRS MORAVEC’s nose is broken. Rivulets of dark blood pour down and off her chin.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHROPOID V20
dialogues.text: The moaning sound that comes from her is almost animalis This is a woman who knows there is no way out of the situation.

dialogues.speaker: FLEISCHER
dialogues.text: Wo sind die fallschirmspringer?

dialogues.speaker: CHULUPSKY
dialogues.text: Where are the parachutists?

dialogues.speaker: MRS MORAVEC
dialogues.text: (holding her mouth, blood flowing) I know . . . nothing. FLEISCHER punches MRS MORAVEC in the face again. She fall the ground with a gurgling moan. CHULUPSKY is physically upset by what he is witnessing. FLEISCHER points at the officers to get MRS MORAVEC back on her feet. ATA struggles against the men that hold him. Tears stream His mouth open but his vocal chords are paralyzed. Two officers help MRS MORAVEC up again. MRS MORAVEC stands facing FLEISCHER but seems to be looki right through him. O.S The trickling sound of water hitting a wood floor. FLEISCHER looks down. MRS MORAVEC is relieving her bladder. A dark patch has sp in the front of her dress and splashes on the wooden floo between her legs. FLEISCHER stares at her in disgust.

dialogues.speaker: FLEISCHER
dialogues.text: Ekelhaft! (beat) Uberall suchen! The officers start to tear the place apart, searching everywhere. FLEISCHER goes next door.

dialogues.speaker: MRS MORAVEC
dialogues.text: (to Chulupsky) Please, let me clean myself up before we leave. (beat) I do not want to make a mess in the car. CHULUPSKY nods assent.

dialogues.speaker: CHULUPSKY
dialogues.text: Go on, Madame.

dialogues.speaker: MRS MORAVEC
dialogues.text: (to Chulupsky, indicating Ata) My son is a violinist. Tell them he knows nothing of this... CHULUPSKY frowns. MRS MORAVEC hobbles to the lavatory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A narrow high-ceilinged room with a WC and above it a cis with a chain. A small window. Two colourful railway compa posters advertising pre-war holiday destinations have bee put on the walls to brighten the room up. MRS MORAVEC hurriedly enters and throws the lock on the d She reaches into the front pockets of her pinafore and pu out a small wooden carving of a German SS officer and a g capsule of cyanide. In CLOSE UP we see her look up to the heavens, tears in h eyes. She holds her hands together and says a very brief prayer and then crosses her chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLEISCHER reenters the room and sees MRS MORAVEC is missi

dialogues.speaker: FLEISCHER
dialogues.text: Wo ist die Frau?

dialogues.speaker: CHULUPSKY
dialogues.text: (pointing) In der toilette.

dialogues.speaker: FLEISCHER
dialogues.text: ScheiBe!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLEISCHER kicks the lavatory door in. The door falls back and MRS MORAVEC is standing there loo straight at FLEISCHER with a strange smile on her face. S then collapses. FLEISCHER rushes to her and slaps her face.

dialogues.speaker: FLEISCHER
dialogues.text: Wasser! He checks her breathing but she looks dead. They try to resuscitate her. She is dead.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHROPOID V20
dialogues.text: 130 131 132 Just out of reach from her dead limp hand we see a CLOSE of the wooden carved SS officer laying on its side. INT. GESTAPO INTERROGATION CELL —- MORNING 130 A windowless cell. A single naked light bulb hangs from t centre of the ceiling. Flaking dark green paint on the wa ATA sits behind a large metal table. A guard stands eithe side of him. ATA is exhausted and badly hurt. He has been heavily beaten. FLEISCHER sits to one side. The TORTURER takes a number o photographs from a folder, portraits of suspected resista fighters, and places them in two rows on the table in fro of ATA, and then with a flourish of his hand ‘invites’ AT study them.

dialogues.speaker: TORTURER
dialogues.text: (German accent throughout) You recognize any of these men? ATA shakes his head no. The TORTURER starts to beat ATA again. He then stops and grabs a picture of VALCIK, thrusts it in ATA’s face.

dialogues.speaker: TORTURER
dialogues.text: (breathing heavily) Recognize him? ATA looks at the photo and says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOSEF and BUBLIK are on guard duty in the nave’s balcony. JOSEF is awake but the boredom has him in his own world d dreaming. He is awoken from this by the sound of whisperi voices. The hushed voices are coming from within the chur JOSEF looks through the balustrades of the balcony to the church below. JOSEF’s POV: the church seems empty but the voices contin OPALKA suddenly exits the confession box. He says somethi inaudible as a parting shot, and then walks towards the crypt. Behind him FATHER PETREK exits the other side of t confession box and walks towards the altar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOSEF descends the stairs to see OPALKA in deep conversat with JAN, VALCIK, and HRUBY. OPALKA turns to see JOSEF.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: What did I miss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bishop Gorazd has told Father Petrek that our presence here is endangering the church and he wants us to leave. (beat) Father Petrek relayed this to Uncle and they have a plan to get us all out.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rain pours down on a black car as it pulls up outside. INT. BLACK CAR - SAME. LADISLAV and UNCLE HAJSKY sit in the car. There is some tension between them.

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: I know things have been, strained between us. I was against the assassination and that may have led to some doubt about my position within the resistance organization. UNCLE HAJSKY looks at LADISLAV.

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: As bad as the reprisals have been, I was wrong, it was right to do it. UNCLE HAJSKY regards LADISLAV.

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: Lets just get the parachutists out of Prague.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: (nods) Meet me round the back in ten minutes. UNCLE HAJSKY exits the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A service is being held. Small and discrete. At the back the chapel UNCLE HAJSKY enters and slots into the pews. He makes eye contact with the UNDERTAKER to the side of t coffin. He is a tall serious man in his fifties dressed i black morning suit. A knowing look is passed between them

dialogues.speaker: ANTHROPOID V20
dialogues.text: 111 INT. UNDERTAKER’S GARAGE - DAY 111 At the back of the chapel there is place where the coffin are loaded onto the cars. Several funeral wreaths lean against the walls. Rain is pouring down. In the backgroun funeral organ music is heard. We see two coffins in the back of a black hearse. Looking down at it is the UNDERTAKER, beside him is LADISLAV and UNCLE HAJSKY. The UNDERTAKER raises the bottom of one of the coffins to reveal a further space underneath

dialogues.speaker: UNDERTAKER
dialogues.text: Two in the coffins. Two under the dummy floors and the other three disguised as pall bearers. (beat) That’s the seven. (beat) The service can be at the Cathedral of Saints Cyril and Methodius and then the burial at Saint Josef and Mary’s church which is outside of Prague. (beat) You then make arrangements to collect them from there. LADISLAV looks at UNCLE HAJSKY. They nod in agreement wit the UNDERTAKER.

dialogues.speaker: UNCLE HAJSKY
dialogues.text: How soon can you be ready?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Several shots of long featureless corridors. Silence. The the distorted sounds of ATA screaming under torture. His screams become distorted and echo down the corridors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now a MS of ATA in his cell dressed in his Sunday best playing a part of Bartok’s ‘Violin Concerto No. 2’. He is immersed in an angelic light. There is a passage in the concerto ATA cannot get right. keeps hitting the wrong note, a jarring almost discordant wrong note that becomes louder and more frequent until it turns into a never ending scream. ATA looks across the cell and sees himself strapped to a heavy wooden chair. The screaming coming from his open mo His face is bloody from the beatings and one eye is swoll shut, the other bloodshot and streaming.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHROPOID V20
dialogues.text: The TORTURER punches him and two men then force brandy d his throat using a funnel and rubber tube.

dialogues.speaker: TORTURER
dialogues.text: You like to play the violin? The torture smashes ATA’s left hand three or four times w hammer. ATA screams until he passes out. A German doctor appears. He holds up a large hypodermic syringe, ATA is injected. A bucket of cold water then is thrown over him. ATA has been broken both physically and mentally. He is n who he was.

dialogues.speaker: TORTURER
dialogues.text: Maybe you would like to see your mother again? The broken ATA looks up through the tears, a glimmer of h

dialogues.speaker: TORTURER
dialogues.text: Yes, we managed to save her... He signals and a man who leaves the room and then re-ente with a METAL BUCKET.

dialogues.speaker: TORTURER
dialogues.text: We saved her head. The man lifts MRS MORAVEC’s decapitated head out of the bucket.

dialogues.speaker: ATA
dialogues.text: (the ATA in the wooden chair)

dialogues.speaker: TORTURER
dialogues.text: (disembodied, echoic) Where are the assassins? (beat) Where are the assassins? (beat) Where are they hiding? (beat) Where are they hiding?

dialogues.speaker: ATA
dialogues.text: (the Ata in his Sunday best) Don’t tell them! (beat) You mustn’t tell them!

dialogues.speaker: TORTURER
dialogues.text: (disembodied, echoic) Where are the assassins? (beat) Where are they hiding?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the ATA in the wooden chair)

dialogues.speaker: ATA
dialogues.text: (the Ata in his Sunday best) You must never say!

dialogues.speaker: TORTURER
dialogues.text: (disembodied, echoic)

dialogues.speaker: WHERE ARE THEY
dialogues.text: He is going to explode out of his body. The violin music louder and louder. It’s going to burst his eardrums. The violin is now mixed with ATA’s screams and the sound buil to a crescendo and then stops as...

dialogues.speaker: ATA
dialogues.text: (the ATA in the wooden chair SCREAMS) THEY’RE IN THE CHURCH!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens on CURDA. He is escorted out of the cell b two guards. On the way out he sees ATA being dragged past and into a cell. ATA’s hands tied behind his back. CURDA looks away, guilt, shame. He continues down the corridor, the camera stays close on face as light and shadow rhythmically cross his face from lights above.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAN, OPALKA, and BUBLIK are on the balcony doing guard du All is silent. All three look exhausted. JAN is staring a his watch. OPALKA is tapping out a beat on the butt of hi rifle. BUBLIK is spinning a coin in the air. Time weighs heavily. 136 INT. UNDERTAKER’S GARAGE - MORNING 136 LADISLAV dressed like the UNDERTAKER. The last of the preparations are under way. Spare pall- bearer’s uniforms are laid out. The empty coffins are clo The garage doors open and the two hearses drive out onto street and off towards the cathedral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAN, OPALKA, and BUBLIK sit patiently, silently. The street outside, usually noisy is now quiet. Too quiet JAN exchanges glances with OPALKA and BUBLIK. JAN creeps to the window and looks down. POV: The street is deserted. The Germans have closed off street at each end with barriers. Suddenly there is a massive build-up of armed troops.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: The Germans are surrounding the church. (beat) We have to warn the others.

dialogues.speaker: OPALKA
dialogues.text: (stopping him) There isn’t time. Take up defensive positions. We hold them from here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The approaching two hearses are forced to stop. LADISLAV is in the passenger seat of the first hearse dre as an undertaker. A German soldier approaches the hearse. Behind we see tro taking up positions around the cathedral.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN SOLDIER
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: LADISLAV
dialogues.text: The other side of town.

dialogues.speaker: GERMAN SOLDIER
dialogues.text: (signalling) Go back. No admittance. The colour drains from LADISLAV’s face as he realises the cathedral will become a tomb for his comrades. The hearse starts to reverse and turns away from the cathedral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first wave of Germans slowly make their way into the church. On the balcony, OPALKA and BUBLIK have taken up defensive positions.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHROPOID V20
dialogues.text: 140 141 JAN and the others look down on the church and see PANNWITZ, a German officer in the Gestapo, and six of his walking through cathedral and cautiously move to the cent JAN'’s POV down from the nave as the soldiers enter. They waiting till as many of the soldiers are gathered before open fire. JAN looks over at OPALKA who gives a nod and then all thr open fire on the Germans below. Several of the Germans are hit and fall. Some fire is returned by the soldiers but they are unsure as to where should be aiming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOSEF, VALCIK, SVARC and HRUBY are awoken by the gunfire jump down from their beds in the wall. They cover their e with their hands. The noise is deafening. JOSEF grabs his STEN.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: We have to help them. JOSEF is restrained by the others.

dialogues.speaker: JOSEF
dialogues.text: (screams up towards the hatch)

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: The others cover his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: VALCIK
dialogues.text: We must not give ourselves away. (beat) The Germans only know about the three on the balcony right now. Not us. JOSEF continues to struggle.

dialogues.speaker: VALCIK
dialogues.text: If it was the other way around would you not want to die knowing your comrades had at least a chance of surviving? JOSEF thinks for a second. They release him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAN finishes a clip and takes cover. The Germans pull out their wounded.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the third floor window across the street we see the German wounded being carried from the cathedral. The Germ machine guns are training on the cathedral windows. INT. CATHEDRAL, BALCONY - MORNING.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Block the stairwell!

dialogues.speaker: OPALKA
dialogues.text: But that is our only way out!

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: It’s also the only way up. JAN, OPALKA, start to throw as much furniture down the stairway that leads up to the balcony as possible. BUBLIK joins in until it’s jammed with furniture. All quiet now. OPALKA winks at JAN and BUBLIK. Silence. T a tremendous roar of automatic fire and crashing glass as teams of German machine gunners opposite the church start strafing the building. There is nothing the three can do except take shelter beh the great stone pillars that rise up in the cathedral, an wait for the firing to cease. JAN looks over BUBLIK. Bullets ricochet around BUBLIK as tries to make himself invisible. BUBLIK starts to panic a hyperventilate.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Bublik! (beat) Bublik! BUBLIK is not there. Tears rolls down his face and he is covering his ears with his hands whilst in the foetal position. JAN slides over to BUBLIK and grabs him. The fire dies down silence again but BUBLIK is still tryi to dig himself in to the stone floor.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Hey! Hey! Breathe! With me. (beat) Big breath in. (beat) Big breath out. JAN grabs a clip and a fistful of ammo from his pocket.

dialogues.speaker: BUBLIK
dialogues.text: I don’t want to die today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mimicking Josef) Here! Look, as we were trained. JAN loads a bullet into the clip.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Nice and easy. You do it. BUBLIK starts to load a bullet into the clip.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: That's it. Easy. (beat) Concentrate on the detail. BUBLIK loads another. The panic attack subsiding.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: It’s OK, Bublik. You are not alone. We are here with you. (beat) And Czechoslovakia is here with us. BUBLIK shakes his head, sniffs back snot and nods. It’s a tender and heart-breaking scene. JAN passing on wh JOSEF had done for him in his time of need. JAN looks over at OPALKA and nods that everything is OK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A detachment of Waffen SS move into position at the front door. Another A detachment of Waffen SS go through FATHER PETREK’s apartment door which is attached at the front of cathedral. INT. CATHEDRAL, BALCONY - MORNING. JAN looks over to the balcony and sees the church swarmin with Germans. JAN, OPALKA and BUBLIK open fire on the Germans below and hell breaks loose again. A German machine gun team enters. They find a position an load. Opening fire at JAN, the wooden balcony splinters i hundreds of pieces as he drops for cover. He pulls a large splinter from between his knuckles. The furniture in the stairwell starts to move.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHROPOID V20
dialogues.text: 144 145 147 BUBLIK ups and runs to see the Germans pulling chairs awa from the stairwell. He opens fire on them dropping two be fierce gunfire is returned and he is forced back into cov INT. UNCLE HAJSKY'S APARTMENT, KITCHEN — DAY 144 UNCLE HAJSKY sits at the table staring into space. A cloc ticks in the room. A startling contrast to the previous scene. UNCLE HAJSKY turns to see: POV: of the front door. Silhouettes can be seen on the ot side of the glass. UNCLE HAJSKY removes his glasses like a man ready to go t sleep at the end of a long day. He places the glasses onto the table and we hold on them CLOSE UP as UNCLE HAJSKY can be seen getting up from the table through the lenses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: UNCLE HAJSKY enters the toilet and closes the door to a crack, peering out, when: The front door bursts open. Shouts as Gestapo officers ru in. UNCLE HAJSKY closes the door, locks it, looks up and take out his cyanide capsule and regards it. Shouting fro outside and someone violently tries the handle to the loc door. UNCLE HAJSKY DROPS THE CAPSULE. He drops to his knees just as the Gestapo open fire. The splinters as bullets rip through the door. UNCLE HAJSKY i his knees looking for the capsule BUT HE DOESN’T HAVE HIS GLASSES. He pats the floor with his hands in order to fee for it. IN EXTREME CLOSE UP his hand makes contact with the capsu and he puts it in his mouth and bites down as the Gestapo kick the door in. UNCLE HAJSKY roles over onto his back looking up at a Ges officer. His look defiant. The Gestapo officer realises and scream the others for help. He tries to lift UNCLE HAJSKY but it too late, he is already dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAN is reloading, he looks over to see OPALKA taking shot the German below. The Germans bring in a box of fragment grenades under hea fire from the balcony.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHROPOID V20
dialogues.text: 148 149 JAN turns to see the furniture cave in down the stairwell

dialogues.speaker: BUBLIK
dialogues.text: BUBLIK looks down to see the Germans pulling furniture fr the stairwell but before he can fire is fired upon and ha take cover.

dialogues.speaker: WE HAVE LOST THE STAIRWELL
dialogues.text: JAN looks at OPALKA and OPALKA up and runs just as two Germans appear at the top of the stairs. JAN fires at them killing them. OPALKA using some bookshelves as cover fires down the stairwell killing another approaching German clambering o the furniture barricade. His gun then clicks empty and he reloads. Suddenly the stairwell is all quiet. Then a grenade is thrown up the stairwell. It bounces off wall and rolls between OPALKA and JAN. JAN sees the grenade and then looks at OPALKA. OPALKA looks at the grenade and then at JAN. JAN dives for cover and the grenade goes off!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The explosion shudders the crypt and dust and cement fall from the ceiling above. The men are all fixated on the no above them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAN recovers to see through the debris that OPALKA is slu against the bookshelves badly wounded. Blood pours from h ears and nose and most of his right side is damaged by th blast. OPALKA takes a cyanide capsule from his jacket collar and puts into his mouth. JAN watches as OPALKA crunches down on the glass. OPALKA then put the pistol to his temple and pulls the trigger. BUBLIK who is on the upper level sees more Germans at the of the stairwell and opens fire but one gets through.

dialogues.speaker: ANTHROPOID V20
dialogues.text: JAN runs up the stairs to the upper level and turns to s the German behind him. JAN opens fire and kills him. His clicks empty.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: taking cover g

dialogues.speaker: I'M OUT
dialogues.text: BUBLIK throws over his last clip.

dialogues.speaker: MY LAST ONE.
dialogues.text: JAN slams the clip home, cocks the weapon and fires back hitting three Germans but one throws up a grenade. JAN runs back through the next arch and takes cover as th grenade explodes behind him.

dialogues.speaker: JAN
dialogues.text: Kurva! A bullet has also scraped his left eyebrow and blood tric down. He tries to swipe it in order to see. Takes his han from his waist belt and sees: BUBLIK firing into the nave from the next arch back. BUBL STEN clicks empty, he drops it and pulls his handgun from waist belt and continues to fire. JAN turns and sees three Germans making their way along t upper level and he fires at them hitting all three. He tu and sees: A grenade bounce off the wall behind BUBLIK, who picks it and throws it into the nave but another is thrown and lan in the last arch behind him. BUBLIK goes to retrieve it.

dialogues.speaker: BUBLIK
